story:
Summary

The Experimental Farm Network (EFN) is asking for your help to raise $132,000. These funds will enable us to build on our groundbreaking work, and in particular to launch an open-source online platform connecting an army of volunteer growers with plant breeders and other agricultural researchers. 

Over the past two and a half years, we've amassed a large and diverse seed collection, developed our flagship farm into a hub for the network, and recruited hundreds of participants already collaborating on important projects. We consider this past work a successful test of our operational model and we look now to you to help us take our next major steps forward.

EFN's chief purpose is to accelerate the pace of innovation in agriculture. We're especially focused on the development of sustainable, carbon-sequestering alternatives to the destructive GMO-corn-&-soy paradigm, which will be of critical importance in this era of accelerating climate change.

Enormous companies like Monsanto & Cargill spend billions each year on agricultural research aimed at little more than corporate profits. We firmly believe that by tapping into our greatest resource—people power!—we can use your investment in this project to change the world for the better.

Heirloom 'Algonquin' Squash seedlings at the EFN flagship farm in Elmer, NJ.


Introduction

EFN aims to fight global climate change by breeding new crop plants and developing improved growing systems with a focus on carbon sequestration and mitigating the effects of climate change. We plan to do this the only way we know how: through facilitating widespread collaboration and cooperation.

The climate crisis threatens life as we know it on this planet. It has already contributed to instability and natural disasters around the world, from Syria and Sudan to New Orleans and New York/New Jersey. While no single solution is big enough to solve this problem, fixing our broken agriculture system would be a huge start. We envision an agriculture that relies on carbon-sequestering perennial plants and organic, agroecological, and permaculture-based systems, as opposed to the energy-intensive, chemical and GMO-based industrial systems that currently dominate farming.

You can read more about climate-stabilizing agriculture on our website.

Founded in 2013 by young farmer/activists Nate Kleinman and Dusty Hinz, EFN is a 501(c)3 non-profit cooperative incorporated in Pennsylvania as The Experimental Farm Network Cooperative. From our home base in the Philadelphia area, including our flagship farm in Elmer, New Jersey, we're building a grassroots army of plant breeders, researchers, and volunteers. For 2015, our pilot year in wide operation, we recruited participants from 44 US states, 4 Canadian provinces, and 15 countries. 

EFN's work with Syrian seeds was covered by The Guardian, Nov. 2015.

Among our successes thus far: we've introduced new crop varieties to American growers (like the Nerum Boer popping sorghum from South Sudan) and saved others from obscurity or extinction (like the 'Tracy' mayapple from Pennsylvania); we've gathered together a world-class Board of Directors, including two living legends, Dr. Vandana Shiva and Dr. William Woys Weaver; and our work has been featured in The Philadelphia Daily News, The Organic Broadcaster, and The Guardian.

Yet despite these successes, we still have a long way to go. If we're to achieve our ambitious goal—crowdsourcing a climate-stabilizing agricultural system—we'll need to expand the network exponentially.

We can't rely on corporations or governments to do this work. We can only rely on ourselves. If we come together on an unprecedented scale, there's no telling what we can achieve.

Perennial leeks springing back to life in Ottawa, Ontario. These leeks are part of the first EFN project in Canada, led by Telsing Andrews. She's a gifted and prolific plant breeder who was one of the first people to sign up and join the network.


How EFN Works to Breed Better Plants

Participatory Plant Breeding

The most important research we facilitate involves good old-fashioned plant breeding (quite distinct from unnatural genetic engineering). Without plant breeding, we would all still be hunter-gatherers. It is a science and an art that requires time, patience, and lots of repetitive work. Success or failure rests on an ability to recognize beneficial traits and rogue mutations, and the chances of success go up with every seed planted. The more seeds you plant, the more likely you'll find something new and useful.

Imagine an ingenious part-time plant breeder working to develop perennial eggplants, for instance. Her perennial eggplants would sequester carbon in the ground and prevent its release by avoiding annual tillage. One summer she might cross a tasty heirloom eggplant with a wild perennial eggplant relative and produce a few dozen fruits through her efforts. Each fruit contains hundreds of seeds. Her little experiment might easily yield 20,000 seeds. Unfortunately, she only has room in her small field for a hundred plants the next year, and even that amount would be challenging for her to plant, weed, evaluate, harvest, and taste-test.

Now imagine this plant breeder is part of a nationwide network of farmers and gardeners like the Experimental Farm Network. She can log on to a website and post her project. Volunteers can sign up to grow for her and she can vet them based on their profile (which would include a score based on past participation). If a volunteer grower has room for 10 plants, she might mail them 30 seeds, with instructions to plant out only the 10 strongest seedlings. A volunteer with space (and time) to grow 100 plants might be mailed 300 seeds, with similar instructions.

With just a couple dozen volunteers and a small investment in postage, her chances for success increase exponentially. She can see grown out in one year what would otherwise take her a lifetime to do herself. Maybe only one of those 20,000 seeds has just the combination of traits she needs—and by tapping into a network like the EFN, she can make sure she finds that one special seed. 

A very rare eggplant from Homs, Syria, at the EFN flagship farm in Elmer, NJ.


Building Community, Building Power

This year, EFN recruited volunteer growers and experiment designers using an online form that plugged participants' information into a giant spreadsheet. Pilot projects included "do nothing" okra, perennial leek breeding, oca for the northern hemisphere, "organic ready" corn,  and improving Tartarian bread plant. EFN co-founders Dusty & Nate spent weeks poring over the spreadsheet, then personally connecting researchers with volunteers by email and telephone. With the first funds raised by this campaign, we plan to build a social network into our website that makes it easy for participants to connect directly to each other.

Ultimately, our goal is to build a massive community of agricultural researchers and volunteers. We believe this is important not only for the development of new crops and growing systems, but for creating new organizational models and regional economies, and building power to counter the short-sighted profit-seeking corporations that have for too long dictated agricultural policy in this country. We need to create viable alternatives to the dominant forces in agriculture, and give farmers the confidence and support to make the switch. If we're ever going to have a climate-stabilizing agricultural system, we need to help farmers wean themselves from GMO-based monoculture—and we believe the best way to do this is through an interconnected community based on mutual aid and solidarity. That's the dream of EFN.

Some of our nearly extinct 'Tracy' Mayapples (Podophyllum peltatum) in bloom in NJ. We rescued this unique variety from obscurity behind a Pennsylvania farmhouse in 2013 following the death of its owners. Mayapples produce both food, in the form of a delicious fruit, and cancer medicine, in the form of a toxin called podophyllin, and these are the largest, most productive mayapples we've ever seen.

Preserving Genetic Diversity at Our Flagship Farm

At our flagship research farm in southern New Jersey, we produce seeds of rare varieties from around the world with a focus on little-known heirlooms, landraces, and crop wild relatives from communities threatened by war, climate change, industrial agriculture, and poverty. Our plants contain within them thousands of years of human history. If they were to disappear, it would mean the loss of precious genetic diversity that could help us both adapt to climate change and fight it. Many of our seeds were received from the US Department of Agriculture (USDA) through the Agricultural Research Service, which has been collecting plants from around the world for over a century. Only in recent years has their entire collection become searchable through an online database, which we believe makes this a moment in history ripe for unparalleled agricultural innovation (plant breeders from just a few decades ago would hardly be able to imagine this incredible resource), but only if we take full advantage of it.

Over the past two years, we've grown out over a thousand different accessions on a few acres—generously provided for us rent-free by a pair of like-minded family farmers—and in the process we've identified some potentially important crops that would otherwise still be languishing in seed banks. Some of our favorites include two perennial sorghum varieties from Zambia, two melons from the Maldives, a cucumber from Bhutan (see below), various perennial cabbage relatives, four frost-hardy jojoba accessions, and a perennial green-bean-equivalent from Turkey and Syria. We're excited to be growing these plants not simply for what they might hold for the future, but for their links to the past. We are eager to return seeds to the communities from which they originated in as many cases as possible (we're already working to return sorghum varieties from South Sudan to the war-torn communities from which they were collected by scientists many decades ago). 

We know there are untold treasures in the USDA's seed banks and in similar institutions throughout the world. We need to develop the capacity among ordinary citizens to engage with these institutions, support their work, and bring valuable lost seeds back from obscurity and into circulation. The agricultural heritage of humanity cannot be preserved in seed banks alone: it must be nurtured, preserved, and improved upon through use. This is a generational task, and none of us can do it alone.

A 19-inch Bhutanese 'Gagon' cucumber grown by an EFN participant in Minnesota.

Our Bottom Line

We've been working full-time on this project for over two years, depleting our personal savings to make the Experimental Farm Network a reality. We believe this effort is so important that we've dedicated our lives to it. We're asking for your help to fund EFN operations for the next two years, after which we fully intend to be self-sufficient. 

In addition to the all-important EFN website, we plan to use the funds from this campaign to help start cooperative micro-enterprises in support of farmers transitioning to more sustainable systems. In particular, we plan to initiate a pilot regional cooperative in southern New Jersey and southeastern Pennsylvania to produce and sell rare seeds, plants, and a few select food products. The proceeds from these sales will support the ongoing work of further growing and maintaining the EFN. 

Your donations now will allow us to achieve self-sufficiency far into the future.

Our budget includes (in order of priority):

1. EFN's online network development - $5,000

2. Improved seed storage facilities & refridgeration - $4,000 

3. Seed packaging & shipping supplies - $3,500

4. Greenhouse with winter heating capability - $6,500

5. Small grain mill - $800

6. Oilseed press - $700

7. Sorghum cane press & evaporator - $2,500

8. Walk-behind tractor & attachments - $5,000 

9. Two full-time staff positions for two years - $80,000

10. Part-time seasonal labor (at $15/hr) - $14,000

11. Solar-powered irrigation system expansion - $2,000

12. Miscellaneous supplies & travel expenses - $8,000

TOTAL: $132,000

A tunnel protects rare heirloom sweet potatoes from groundhogs at the EFN flagship farm in Elmer, NJ, as our solar-powered irrigation system feeds pond-water to various seeds in June 2015.

We Promise:

  • To work every day to see the Experimental Farm Network reach its full potential. 
  • To maintain our focus on sustainability, climate change mitigation, and climate stabilization. 
  • To spend your money wisely and report back to you with all of our successes and failures. 
  • To continue working cooperatively and transparently at every turn. 
  • To keep fighting for better agriculture policy in the United States.
  • To stay committed to social, racial, and economic justice. 
  • To make a difference.

How You Can Help:

  • Please donate here!
  • Like us on facebook.
  • Follow us on Instagram.
  • Visit our website.
  • Join the EFN as an experiment designer or volunteer grower.
  • Share this campaign with everyone you know!

THANK YOU!

A salt-marsh near EFN's flagship farm in southern New Jersey, along the Delaware Bay: one of many ecosystems threatened by both the pollution of industrial farming and the sea-level-rise caused by global warming. Help us preserve this landscape and the lives that depend on it. Please donate today.

story:
Phebe Hospital in Liberia spends $35,000 every month on diesel fuel to run its generators and provide essential electricity for its operations. For the first hospital in Liberia that faced a patient with Ebola, this is incredibly expensive, unsustainable, and unreliable.

Our Goal of $35,000 = one months' diesel fuel bill at Phebe Hospital

 

"Many times, so many times Dr. Sibley has gone into the operating room in darkness because there is no power. Sometimes the generators are down, sometimes the diesel has not arrived yet." 
-Josephine Kantan, Head of Generator Operations at Phebe Hospital


Phebe Hospital and School of Nursing used to be part of Liberia’s central electric grid infrastructure. The hospital used to be one of the most advanced in the country.  Then the bloody and destructive civil war started, and subsequently destroyed much of the infrastructure in Liberia, which including the dismantling of central power grid. The war ended in 2003, but Liberia has struggled to rebuild, with still only about 1% of Liberians having access to the electric grid in Monrovia.

"Sometimes especially in the rainy season, the roads get so bad that the trucks bringing the diesel get stuck in the mud for days. Since they are unable to reach us, we are working in the darkness. Hospitals need electricity to operate, so if we had access to solar energy that would be a lifesaver." 
-Dr. Sibley, Medical Director



Phebe Hospital serves a population of 450,000 in rural Liberia, seeing over 30,000 patients every year. They spend $35,000 every month on diesel fuel to run their generators. It would take the average Liberian 77 years to earn enough money to pay for one months' worth of Phebe Hospital's power bills!

                                                       

                         

                  

Delivery expenses of diesel fuel add to the already high cost, while the environmental costs are not only limited to what comes out of the smoke stack, but what leaks onto the ground.

The Ground around the generator building is saturated with diesel fuel.

                  

                       

Opportunities for a new model of development are created where there is a lack of central electric grid. Just as many countries in Africa have skipped the telephone landline infrastructure and gone straight to cell phone communication, rural communities have the opportunity to Skip the electric Grid. Local communities can take control of their energy future by generating their own renewable power, right where it is consumed.

We can change the situation for Phebe! We will empower Phebe Hospital and School of Nursing, Liberia, West Africa with solar energy.

Help us provide Phebe with access to reliable zero emissions renewable energy to save lives and make the planet a little more green.

In a nutshell, a PV-diesel-battery microgrid makes usable energy from the sun, and it can be directly used by loads, and stored by batteries for later use. If there is not enough energy being produced by the PV array due to cloud cover, then the system will turn on a back-up generator.

PV for Phebe is a project of RREAL, the Rural Renewable Energy Alliance, and our partners. RREAL was founded in 2000, to solve fuel poverty with solar energy, balancing the use of advanced technology with the interests of our environment while bringing lasting independence, economic and social change to communities. RREAL is a 501(c)(3), tax-exempt nonprofit organization that has been delivering solar energy to low-income individuals and communities since our inception.

                         

Our staff electricians, contractors, technicians and engineers have over 50 years’ experience specifically in solar project management and development, and have NABCEP (North American Board of Certified Energy Practitioners) certification.

We tackle social, economic, and environmental justice issues with solar power. We believe that solar energy can be used as a vehicle to address poverty in America and on the rest of the planet. Solar is a powerful and empowering solution!

       Follow us on our main FB page, FB Project page, Twitter, or Instagram.

                                     

                  

                 

Phebe Hospital is like a miniature city, with masons, electricians, cabinet builders, and more. Phebe will do site preparation work prior to the arrival of equipment and the RREAL team, including construction of the balance of system facility. Phebe’s electricians will complete the system installation, and operations and maintenance training with RREAL’s team. Phebe electricians already have experience in completing off-grid solar electric installations on rural health clinics affiliated with Phebe, so they come with valuable experience. Phebe will further supply room and board while the RREAL installation and training team is on the ground.

The NE MN Women of the ELCA (Evangelical Lutheran Church of America) mobilize women to act boldly on their faith in Jesus Christ. The Women of the ELCA traveled to be inspired by the bold women of Liberia who played a significant role in ending the civil war there, and they indeed got inspired. During their stay in Liberia, they visited Phebe Hospital, and asked Medical Director Dr. Sibley what his biggest challenge was. Expecting disease, or some other issue to be the biggest difficulty, they were shocked when he responded, “power.” With bountiful sunshine as a resource, Dr. Sibley and the Women of the ELCA resolved that solar power could bring relief to Phebe’s health care infrastructure. And the Women of the ELCA determined to do something about it. The NE MN Women of the ELCA pledged to raise $200,000 for the project.

Global Health Ministries has a vision to change the world through building partnerships that result in thriving community health systems that are measurably stronger, more effective and sustainable. With their considerable experience in international logistics and years of sending shipments to Liberia, including solar systems, they will help ensure products arrive safely and in a timely fashion to Liberia. Global Health Ministries regularly sends shipments of medical and other supplies to Phebe Hospital and supports many other clinics and hospitals around the globe.

University of St Thomas’ Dr. Greg Mowry, Director of the Renewable Energy and Alternatives Laboratory, is experienced in designing renewable energy microgrids, with completed projects at the University of Moldova, for a 150-bed hospital in Tanzania, rural villages in Uganda, as well as microgrid projects in the United States. Dr. Mowry’s power engineering team provides technical assistance. 

                                                    

 The Lutheran Church in Liberia owns the land at Phebe Hospital.  The equipment shipped will be consigned to the Lutheran Church in Liberia and as such will not be subject to duties and tariffs.  Liberian Customs consistently treats shipments with courtesy and expedites the process.

                             


We’ve developed a proven way of reducing energy poverty. We need your help to buy, ship, and assemble the photovoltaic systems at the Phebe Hospital. The Women of ELCA have adopted a resolution to support this project, but we still do not have enough money to afford the equipment necessary for this project.

 

    

      

  

The area of the world we know today as Liberia was founded and controlled by former African American slaves.  Liberia declared independence in 1847.  The country continued to be in the American sphere of influence, and became dominated by the small minority of black colonists and their descendants.  Ultimately, this continued domination by a few and suppression of the majority helped lead to the protracted civil war which significantly contributed to unrest leading to a coup d'etat in 1980.

The women in Liberia organized, including all religious groups and classes, and throughout 2002-3 successfully forced the warring factions to make peace, without any weapons beyond their force of will. Two Liberian women won Nobel Peace prizes as a result of their incredible efforts, the current President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf, and Leymah Gbowee.

The area where Phebe Hospital is located was one of the strongholds for some of the fighting groups, and Phebe had to evacuate on numerous occasions due to the chaos taking place around them. The dedicated staff evacuated to a safer area, and reopened there, returning to the hospital grounds when the situation calmed, refusing to close operations throughout the entire civil war. The hospital grounds were looted and ransacked repeatedly, with combatants ultimately removing almost everything they could, including connections to the central grid and wire, to generators, light bulbs and even toilets. Phebe Hospital & School of Nursing has been slowly rebuilding since that time, and then Ebola emerged, setting the entire country back.

       

Phebe Hospital & School of Nursing was founded by Lutheran, Methodist, and Episcopalian Churches in 1921. Lutheran Church support has dwindled over the years, and Methodist and Episcopalian Church support has all but evaporated as they focus on other priorities.

         

What is the goal?


This project will install a PV-diesel-battery microgrid that will cover the majority of Phebe Hospital, Phebe School of Nursing, and the Bong County Health Department daytime energy needs. The solar electric array will include a small amount of battery back-up for periods without direct sunlight, and will have the capability to turn on the backup generator when needed. 

Will Phebe staff be able to maintain the system?

Phebe staff have the experience, tools, and skill set required in order to maintain the system. The generator building is currently staffed 24 hours per day, 7 days per week, and these staff will be utilized in order to maintain the PV microgrid. Staff electricians have already installed over 20 small solar electric systems for the regional health clinics, and this experience will facilitate learning a similar system.

When will it be completed?

The system will be installed and commissioned 5 months after we achieve the required funding level to ship components and complete the system installation and training, once we have $600,000 in hand.

Is this complicated?

Significant time and dedication is required to design the system properly, and ensure it is executed correctly. But, systems like this are becoming more and more common, and they are deployed all over the world where there is no central electric grid.

Where do your people come from?

A small team from RREAL will join the Phebe staff during the installation and training.

Do you need permission from local authorities to install solar?

Because this system will be installed on private property held by the Lutheran Church in Liberia, we will not need permission from local authorities.

Are you worried about someone stealing the equipment?

The site selected for the installation will be conveniently located directly across from the security gate at Phebe, which is always staffed. It will also be fenced in and topped with razor wire.

You may contact us or mail donations to:

                                                              RREAL                                                                                                          2330 Dancing Wind Rd. SW, Suite #2                                                                                       Pine River, MN 56474

                                                        www.rreal.org

                                                      +1-218-587-4753

                                                      

Help us Bring Solar Power to Phebe Hospital!

1. Donate a buck for every light switch in your house, or if you can't count that high, donate 10 bucks.

2. Post a video of you and your family or friends doing an everyday activity in the dark (with your clothes on please) to your favorite Social Media, with the hashtags #DoItIntheDark and #SolarAssistance . Since you'll be recording in the dark, you will have to get creative!!!

3. Dare your friends to "Do it in the dark"! If they don't take up the challenge, ask them to donate double, 2 bucks for every light switch AND outlet in their house, or if they can't count that high, 20 bucks!

4. Follow us on our main FB page, FB Project page, Twitter, or Instagram.

Thank you,

The RREAL People
story_txt:
Phebe Hospital in Liberia spends $35,000 every month on diesel fuel to run its generators and provide essential electricity for its operations. For the first hospital in Liberia that faced a patient with Ebola, this is incredibly expensive, unsustainable, and unreliable.
Our Goal of $35,000 = one months' diesel fuel bill at Phebe Hospital




 


"Many
times, so many times Dr. Sibley has gone into the operating room in darkness
because there is no power. Sometimes the generators are down, sometimes the
diesel has not arrived yet." -Josephine Kantan, Head of Generator Operations
at Phebe Hospital

Phebe Hospital and School of Nursing used to be part of Liberia’s central electric grid infrastructure. The hospital used to be one of the most advanced in the country.  Then the bloody and destructive civil war started, and subsequently destroyed much of the infrastructure in Liberia, which including the dismantling of central power grid. The war ended in 2003, but Liberia has struggled to rebuild, with still only about 1% of Liberians having access to the electric grid in Monrovia.



"Sometimes
especially in the rainy season, the roads get so bad that the trucks bringing
the diesel get stuck in the mud for days. Since they are unable to reach us, we
are working in the darkness. Hospitals need electricity to operate, so if we
had access to solar energy that would be a lifesaver." -Dr. Sibley,
Medical Director


Phebe Hospital serves a population of 450,000
in rural Liberia, seeing over 30,000 patients every year. They spend $35,000
every month on diesel fuel to run their generators. It would take the average
Liberian 77 years to earn enough money to pay for one months' worth of Phebe
Hospital's power bills!                                                       


                         

                  
Delivery expenses of diesel fuel add to the already high cost, while the environmental costs are not only limited to what comes out of the smoke stack, but what leaks onto the ground.
The Ground around the
generator building is saturated with diesel fuel.

                  
                       
Opportunities
for a new model of development are created where there is a lack of central
electric grid. Just as many countries in Africa have skipped the telephone landline
infrastructure and gone straight to cell phone communication, rural communities
have the opportunity to Skip the electric Grid. Local communities can take
control of their energy future by generating their own renewable power, right
where it is consumed.
We
can change the situation for Phebe! We will empower Phebe Hospital and School
of Nursing, Liberia, West Africa with solar energy.
Help
us provide Phebe with access to reliable zero emissions renewable energy to
save lives and make the planet a little more green.

In
a nutshell, a PV-diesel-battery microgrid makes usable energy from the sun, and
it can be directly used by loads, and stored by batteries for later use. If
there is not enough energy being produced by the PV array due to cloud cover,
then the system will turn on a back-up generator. 


PV for Phebe is a project of RREAL, the Rural
Renewable Energy Alliance, and our partners. RREAL was founded in 2000, to
solve fuel poverty with solar energy, balancing the use of advanced technology
with the interests of our environment while bringing lasting independence,
economic and social change to communities. RREAL is a 501(c)(3), tax-exempt
nonprofit organization that has been delivering solar energy to low-income individuals
and communities since our inception.
                         
Our staff electricians, contractors, technicians and engineers have over
50 years’ experience specifically in solar project management and development,
and have NABCEP (North American Board of Certified Energy Practitioners)
certification.

We tackle social, economic, and environmental
justice issues with solar power. We believe that solar energy can be used as a
vehicle to address poverty in America and on the rest of the planet. Solar
is a powerful and empowering solution!
       Follow us on our main FB page, FB Project page, Twitter, or Instagram.

                                     
                  


                 
Phebe
Hospital is like a miniature city, with masons,
electricians, cabinet builders, and more. Phebe will do site preparation work
prior to the arrival of equipment and the RREAL team, including construction of
the balance of system facility. Phebe’s electricians will complete the system
installation, and operations and maintenance training with RREAL’s team. Phebe electricians
already have experience in completing off-grid solar electric installations on
rural health clinics affiliated with Phebe, so they come with valuable
experience. Phebe will further supply room and board while the RREAL
installation and training team is on the ground.




The NE MN Women of the ELCA (Evangelical Lutheran Church of
America) mobilize women to act boldly on their faith in Jesus Christ. The Women
of the ELCA traveled to be inspired by the bold women of Liberia who played a
significant role in ending the civil war there, and they indeed got inspired.
During their stay in Liberia, they visited Phebe Hospital, and asked Medical
Director Dr. Sibley what his biggest challenge was. Expecting disease, or some
other issue to be the biggest difficulty, they were shocked when he responded,
“power.” With bountiful sunshine as a resource, Dr. Sibley and the Women of the
ELCA resolved that solar power could bring relief to Phebe’s health care
infrastructure. And the Women of the ELCA determined to do something about it.
The NE MN Women of the ELCA pledged to raise $200,000 for the project. 
Global
Health Ministries has a vision to change the world through building
partnerships that result in thriving community health systems that are
measurably stronger, more effective and sustainable. With their considerable
experience in international logistics and years of sending shipments to
Liberia, including solar systems, they will help ensure products arrive safely
and in a timely fashion to Liberia. Global Health Ministries regularly sends
shipments of medical and other supplies to Phebe Hospital and supports many
other clinics and hospitals around the globe.
University of St Thomas’ Dr. Greg Mowry, Director
of the Renewable Energy and Alternatives Laboratory, is experienced in
designing renewable energy microgrids, with completed projects at the
University of Moldova, for a 150-bed hospital in Tanzania, rural villages in
Uganda, as well as microgrid projects in the United States. Dr. Mowry’s power
engineering team provides technical assistance. 


                                                    
 The Lutheran Church in Liberia owns the land at Phebe Hospital.  The equipment shipped will be consigned to the Lutheran Church in Liberia and as such will not be subject to duties and tariffs.  Liberian Customs consistently treats shipments with courtesy and expedites the process.

                             

We’ve developed a proven way of reducing
energy poverty. We need your help to buy, ship, and assemble the photovoltaic
systems at the Phebe Hospital. The Women of ELCA have adopted a resolution to
support this project, but we still do not have enough money to afford the
equipment necessary for this project.


     
      
  
The area of the world we know today as Liberia was founded and controlled by former African American slaves.  Liberia declared independence in 1847.  The country continued to be in the American sphere of influence, and became dominated by the small minority of black colonists and their descendants.  Ultimately, this continued domination by a few and suppression of the majority helped lead to the protracted civil war which significantly contributed to unrest leading to a coup d'etat in 1980.
The women in Liberia organized, including all religious groups and classes, and throughout 2002-3 successfully forced the warring factions to make peace, without any weapons beyond their force of will. Two Liberian women won Nobel Peace prizes as a result of their incredible efforts, the current President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf, and Leymah Gbowee.
The area where Phebe Hospital is located was one of the strongholds for some of the fighting groups, and Phebe had to evacuate on numerous occasions due to the chaos taking place around them. The dedicated staff evacuated to a safer area, and reopened there, returning to the hospital grounds when the situation calmed, refusing to close operations throughout the entire civil war. The hospital grounds were looted and ransacked repeatedly, with combatants ultimately removing almost everything they could, including connections to the central grid and wire, to generators, light bulbs and even toilets. Phebe Hospital & School of Nursing has been slowly rebuilding since that time, and then Ebola emerged, setting the entire country back.
       
Phebe Hospital & School of Nursing was founded by Lutheran, Methodist, and Episcopalian Churches in 1921. Lutheran Church support has dwindled over the years, and Methodist and Episcopalian Church support has all but evaporated as they focus on other priorities.
         
What is the goal?

This project will install a PV-diesel-battery microgrid that will cover
the majority of Phebe Hospital, Phebe School of Nursing, and the Bong County
Health Department daytime energy needs. The solar electric array will include a
small amount of battery back-up for periods without direct sunlight, and will
have the capability to turn on the backup generator when needed.  
Will Phebe staff be able to maintain the
system?
Phebe staff have the experience, tools, and skill set required in order
to maintain the system. The generator building is currently staffed 24 hours
per day, 7 days per week, and these staff will be utilized in order to maintain
the PV microgrid. Staff electricians have already installed over 20 small solar
electric systems for the regional health clinics, and this experience will
facilitate learning a similar system.
When will it be completed?
The system will be installed and commissioned 5 months after we achieve
the required funding level to ship components and complete the system
installation and training, once we have $600,000 in hand. 
Is this complicated?
Significant time and dedication is required to design the system
properly, and ensure it is executed correctly. But, systems like this are
becoming more and more common, and they are deployed all over the world where
there is no central electric grid.
Where do your people come from?
A small team from RREAL will join the Phebe staff during the installation
and training.
Do you need permission from local
authorities to install solar?
Because this system will be installed on private property held by the
Lutheran Church in Liberia, we will not need permission from local authorities.
Are you worried about someone stealing the
equipment?
The site selected for the installation will be conveniently located
directly across from the security gate at Phebe, which is always staffed. It
will also be fenced in and topped with razor wire. 
You may contact us or mail donations to:
                                                              RREAL                                                                                                          2330 Dancing Wind Rd. SW, Suite #2                                                                                       Pine River, MN 56474
                                                        www.rreal.org
                                                      +1-218-587-4753


                                                      





Help us Bring Solar Power to Phebe Hospital!
1. Donate a buck for every light switch in your house, or if you can't count that high, donate 10 bucks.
2. Post a video of you and your family or friends doing an everyday activity in the dark (with your clothes on please) to your favorite Social Media, with the hashtags #DoItIntheDark and #SolarAssistance . Since you'll be recording in the dark, you will have to get creative!!!
3. Dare your friends to "Do it in the dark"! If they don't take up the challenge, ask them to donate double, 2 bucks for every light switch AND outlet in their house, or if they can't count that high, 20 bucks!
4. Follow us on our main FB page, FB Project page, Twitter, or Instagram.
Thank you,

story:
La délégation étudiante de l’Université de Sherbrooke à la CdP-21

Pourquoi la CdP-21 ?

La 21e Conférence des Parties (CdP-21) se déroulera du 30 novembre au 11 décembre 2015 à Paris. Tout le monde en parle. Jamais il n'y avait eu autant d'efforts pour rassembler les États du monde à s'entendre sur une problématique globale comme le climat depuis le Protocole de Kyoto. Depuis la Conférence de Copenhague de 2009, des années de travail ont permis à la cause climatique de gagner un important élan vers un accord mondial qui changera l'histoire.

Notre projet est de constituer une délégation étudiante de l'UdeS en vue d'observer et d'analyser les négociations climatiques dans le cadre de la Conférence de Paris sur le climat; il s’agit de la cinquième délégation que l’École de politique appliquée de l’UdeS forme afin d’assister aux CdPs sur les changements climatiques. Formée de huit étudiants provenant de plusieurs disciplines (politique, droit, administration, génie et histoire), notre délégation de l'UdeS a pour mission de recueillir de l'information nouvelle et actuelle lors de la CdP-21 pour être en mesure de la synthétiser, la divulguer et en faire la promotion. Par ailleurs, l'ensemble des membres de la délégation travaille à la rédaction de recherches en partenariat avec plusieurs organisations québécoises intéressées par l'enjeu climatique et souhaitant recevoir nos travaux.

Nous avons besoin de votre aide !

Les besoins financiers de la délégation s’élèvent à environ 28 470 $. Ce montant comprend principalement les billets d’avion (départ le 27 novembre), l’hébergement, les dépenses relatives à la nourriture et d’autres dépenses nécessaires (notamment : cellulaires, déplacement sur place, assurances voyage ainsi que compensation carbone, etc.).  Les billets sont achetés, l'habitation réservée... nous y allons, coûte que coûte !

Plusieurs demandes de financement sont en cours auprès d’entreprises qui ont l'environnement à cœur et des ministères concernés par la CdP-21. Par ailleurs, le 18 novembre prochain, un important colloque est organisé par la délégation afin d’offrir une plateforme de visibilité à nos donateurs et auquel nous avons la présence confirmée de l'ancien Premier ministre du Québec M. Jean Charest comme conférencier d’honneur. Finalement, plusieurs activités de financement sont organisées. Allez voir notre programme en ligne en cliquant ici !

Vous donnez plus de 300$ ? Songez à nous écrire avant de contribuer ! Vous êtes éligible à être un commanditaire régulier et pouvez ainsi recevoir de la visibilité pour votre organisation. Nous avons donc besoin d'une preuve de votre don.

Si vous ne pouvez pas contribuer financièrement, vous pouvez nous aider malgré tout ! Vous pouvez partager notre page facebook, notre colloque Penser loin dans un Québec vert, et notre vidéo promotionnel sur vos réseaux sociaux. 


Merci à tous nos supporteurs ! :D

story:
FREE PERK-LIMITED TIME

Extra-Large 8ft. Traditional O‘ahu Map (click here)

____________________

HŌ MAI KA PONO

 Redefining Sustainability

"Hō Mai Ka Pono" is a Hawaiian phrase that emphasizes the profound healing process needed to restore the environment to a sustainable state.  The word pono describes the bare essence of our connection to ourselves and the natural world.  The feeling of pono guides our sense of balance, harmony and connection.  The understanding of pono guided traditional sustainability practices which allowed for the land and people to thrive.   Pono is the timeless universal principle underneath all the layers of environmental sustainability.

Read more about an interpretation of the word pono here

____________________

Movie

A documentary film about understanding our relationship with the environment through the lens of traditional thought

Hō Mai Ka Pono is a documentary film that explores the fundamental relationship between humanity and the environment.  Underneath layers of contemporary thought lies timeless understandings of both ourselves and the natural world.  This relationship has always existed and will continue well beyond our time.  Specific emphasis will be placed on understanding O‘ahu from the perspective of traditional thought. 


Audience

All people connected to Hawai‘i- residents, visitors and the global community

This movie is designed to engage people in Hawai‘i, both native and non-native.  The message of this film is inclusive of Hawai‘iʻs visitors as well as the global community. 


Interviews

Interviews provide the dialogue of this film.  Traditional thought is explained by native Hawaiians.  People who help perpetuate the health of the physical, spiritual and social environment in Hawai‘i regardless of ethnicity also provide insight.  Click here to see current interviews.  The perspectives share insight to help us realign with the environment through understanding the fundamental principles of environmental sustainability.

Redefining Sustainability

Sustainability is a concept that is often interpreted from a "western" perspective of the environment.  In essence the environment is an amazingly beautiful and complex interconnected physical and spiritual system that is in perpetual motion.   In Hawai‘i and throughout the world, it was through traditional understandings that countless social systems could be designed to match both the physical and spiritual environment of a place.  The core principle of this design was (and remains today) that for any human system to remain sustainable each individual must take responsibility for maintaining a sense of pono within themselves.  With pono comes the balance and clarity of vision that enabled people and places to thrive.  The deeper reality is that when the collective vision of people becomes blurred it will literally manifest in the environment.


The term "Hō Mai Ka Pono" implies that it is time to embrace and practice this higher level of traditional thought

This movie articulates the profound intelligence of traditional indigenous thought that exists in Hawai‘i.  Indigenous cultures throughout the world carry an active environmental memory that is invaluable in shaping a world more attuned with cycles of the natural world.  In a greater sense it is important to recognize that each individual regardless of ethnicity carries this intelligence.  Rediscovering the fundamental relationship between humanity and the environment includes us all.

____________________

Website



The Hō Mai Ka Pono website shares a comprehensive perspective on our current environmental paradigm through the lens of traditional thought.  The website is an extension of the movie and offers a library of:

-Articles-
-Interviews-
-Maps-
-Resources-
-Photography-
-Videos-

There are numerous high resolution maps of traditional O‘ahu for download

Take a tour of the website

Production & fundraising schedule

Fundraising begins March, 2016 (ongoing throughout production period) 

Phase 1:  Preliminary cinematography, design and film teaser by May, 2016 

Phase 2:  Principle cinematography from May to November, 2016 

Phase 3:  Additional cinematography and final design until early 2017

Release:  March, 2017

_____________________


BACKGROUND


About

The Hō Mai Ka Pono project exists through relationships with people who perpetuate the physical, spiritual and social health of Hawai‘i.  Relationships with kūpuna (elders) and specific places provide insight into traditional concepts as understood traditionally.  While relationships with people and places are the foundation of learning, academic research adds an invaluable intellectual component to this project.


Perspectives

-Sustainability is an exercise in conflict resolution-

-Indigenous People play an important role in our collective healing (read)- 

-The restoration process of specific environments is inclusive of everyone-

-The "environment" is a living physical, spiritual and social system-

-The health of the environment is a reflection of our thoughts, actions and values-

-Differentiating between western and traditional thought-

-Revisiting and deconstructing history to understand our current paradigm-

-Understanding imbalances related to pollution and agriculture (including gmo)-

-Changes at the local, state and global level start with each individual first-

-Each person has a unique role in a sustainable system:  physical, spiritual & social-


Supporting this project

There are financial practicalities of managing and designing a film and website of this proportion.  This fundraising campaign is for completing Phase 1:  preliminary cinematography, design and film teaser.  This project is not connected to any political, federal or state institution and would ideally be suited for sponsorship from an organization that aligns with its principles.  

Major decisions that affect this project are made in coordination with people (especially kūpuna- elders) and places.  The film and website are interconnected so fundraising supports both endeavors.  By April, 2016 webinars, collaborations, presentations and discussions will become part of the project and continue indefinitely.  All collaborations whether spiritual, physical or financial allow this project to fulfill a vision of helping in the restoration of the environment.


Visit the Hō Mai Ka Pono Website to learn more

Interviews provide the dialogue of this film.  Traditional thought is explained by native Hawaiians.  People who help perpetuate the health of the physical, spiritual and social environment in Hawai‘i regardless of ethnicity also provide insight.  Click here to see current interviews.  The perspectives share insight to help us realign with the environment through understanding the fundamental principles of environmental sustainability.






Redefining Sustainability
Sustainability is a concept that is often interpreted from a "western" perspective of the environment.  In essence the environment is an amazingly beautiful and complex interconnected physical and spiritual system that is in perpetual motion.   In Hawai‘i and throughout the world, it was through traditional understandings that countless social systems could be designed to match both the physical and spiritual environment of a place.  The core principle of this design was (and remains today) that for any human system to remain sustainable each individual must take responsibility for maintaining a sense of pono within themselves.  With pono comes the balance and clarity of vision that enabled people and places to thrive.  The deeper reality is that when the collective vision of people becomes blurred it will literally manifest in the environment.

The term "Hō Mai Ka Pono" implies that it is time to embrace and practice this higher level of traditional thought
This movie articulates the profound intelligence of traditional indigenous thought that exists in Hawai‘i.  Indigenous cultures throughout the world carry an active environmental memory that is invaluable in shaping a world more attuned with cycles of the natural world.  In a greater sense it is important to recognize that each individual regardless of ethnicity carries this intelligence.  Rediscovering the fundamental relationship between humanity and the environment includes us all.____________________
Website

The Hō Mai Ka Pono website shares a comprehensive perspective on our current environmental paradigm through the lens of traditional thought.  The website is an extension of the movie and offers a library of:


-Articles--Interviews--Maps--Resources--Photography--Videos-

There are numerous high resolution maps of traditional O‘ahu for download
Take a tour of the website



Production & fundraising schedule




Fundraising begins March, 2016 (ongoing throughout production period) 

Phase 1:  Preliminary cinematography, design and film teaser by May, 2016 

Phase 2:  Principle cinematography from May to November, 2016 

Phase 3:  Additional cinematography and final design until early 2017


Release:  March, 2017
_____________________

BACKGROUND

About
The Hō Mai Ka Pono project exists through relationships with people who perpetuate the physical, spiritual and social health of Hawai‘i.  Relationships with kūpuna (elders) and specific places provide insight into traditional concepts as understood traditionally.  While relationships with people and places are the foundation of learning, academic research adds an invaluable intellectual component to this project.


Perspectives

-Sustainability is an exercise in conflict resolution-
-Indigenous People play an important role in our collective healing (read)- 
-The restoration process of specific environments is inclusive of everyone-
-The "environment" is a living physical, spiritual and social system-
-The health of the environment is a reflection of our thoughts, actions and values-
-Differentiating between western and traditional thought-
-Revisiting and deconstructing history to understand our current paradigm-
-Understanding imbalances related to pollution and agriculture (including gmo)-
-Changes at the local, state and global level start with each individual first-
-Each person has a unique role in a sustainable system:  physical, spiritual & social-

Supporting this project
There are financial practicalities of managing and designing a film and website of this proportion.  This fundraising campaign is for completing Phase 1:  preliminary cinematography, design and film teaser.  This project is not connected to any political, federal or state institution and would ideally be suited for sponsorship from an organization that aligns with its principles.  
Major decisions that affect this project are made in coordination with people (especially kūpuna- elders) and places.  The film and website are interconnected so fundraising supports both endeavors.  By April, 2016 webinars, collaborations, presentations and discussions will become part of the project and continue indefinitely.  All collaborations whether spiritual, physical or financial allow this project to fulfill a vision of helping in the restoration of the environment.

Visit the Hō Mai Ka Pono Website to learn more

story:
Over 3 mln trees felled in 2017

Trees in Poland are disappearing! Changes in the legislation weakened tree protection in our country and caused an environmental disaster. We are loosing milions of trees in cities and the countryside, along roads and in woodlands and only very few are being replaced. It's hard to move anywhere without seeing felled trees. With loosing the oldest and hollow trees we are loosing the rarest terrestial habitat with it's unique, vulnerable and protected species that live in them.  
Even the Europe`s last pristine forest - Bialowieża Forest - is being logged.
 
 

Why protect trees?

Because we cannot become trees!

     

Trees are important for all of us - not just for nature! 

During heat waves they cool air through the transpiration process, contributing to the reduction of ambient temperature by up to 11 degrees. They eliminate up to 75% of dust, reduce up to 98% nitrates and deactivate up to 70% of heavy metals. 

Trees also make natural noise barriers, relieve stress, contribute to property prices and increase the economic potential of cities. They provide a habitat for protected species (bats, birds, beetles, etc.) and are simply beautiful. 

The solution

Citizens have the power to limit and stop the felling of old trees in Poland. By acting locally we can make change at the national level. We need trained tree wardens in every corner of the country so that they can act and object against unneccessary tree removal. To do so effectively they need to be competent and professional. 

    We will only save the trees with joint action!

    What We Need & What You Get

    We need support – national and international – for our work. This is more important than ever because the current Polish government does not appreciate trees and discriminates against those who try to protect them. 

    Thanks to your support we will be able to:

    • provide substantial training for our volunteer tree wardens around the country
    • provide support through infoline and online advice service 
    • engage with local communities through local planting actions
    • provide networking opportunities for tree wardens by organising worshops, seminars and conferences
    • raise the profile of our challenge at the international level
    • influence change in the legislation so that trees receive better protection

    Our minimum goal - 6000$ will allow us to run the consultation point for tree wardens throughout 2018. It should be enough to pay for 200 professional consultations - a real chance of saving hundreds of trees.

    Each additional 1500$ will allow us to organise a one-day training for 25 tree wardens. The more funding we receive the more intensive our activities will be and in result the more trees will be saved.

    Every year we organise a national Tree Friends Forum. This is an opportunity for networking, sharing best practices and inspiring each other (here you can see a glimpse from 2017 TFF: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Zn9YHag9tuQ ). Organising this event costs around 5000-8000$, thanks to your support will make our Tree Friends Forum 2018 bigger and better. 

    In return we will share with you some of our precious books and films that we've created over the last few years to promote trees and help those who are responsible for their maintenance. Here is a trailer of the film "The Secret Life of Trees" that you might receive in return for your support:

     

    About us

    We are a non-profit organization created 26 years ago in Poland during the transition era. Since the beginning we have been protecting trees, making an effort to do so effectively and professionally. We have published books on tree management and trained over 5000 tree officers, road managers and activists. We have conducted local campaigns to protect trees throughout the country.

    Read more about our activities on http://aleje.org.pl/en/

story:
WE CAN PROTECT THE CROCODILES BY RAISING AWARENESS AND TAKING ACTION

We want to contribute to the protection of the crocodile in Costa Rica by educating and strengthening local communities who are sharing their territories with these amazing creatures, sometimes at great risk. We plan to do this by publishing a photo book and do a traveling photographic exhibition around a controversial local tradition, called the “largateada”. The objective is to raise awareness and educate local communities. At same time we mean to sensitize governmental and environmental actors to the challenges local communities face when they cohabit with crocodiles. Our primary goal is education in order to raise awareness. We believe that only through awareness will we be able to guarantee the conservation of the species and a sustainable interaction between crocodiles and humans.

But WE NEED YOU in order to get this book in the hands of those who most need it.

We are a multidisciplinary team. I am a documentary photographer with many years of work accompanying social causes and fighting for human rights and Gabriela Segura is a psychologist with experience working with communities. We care about communities, especially the ones that are more vulnerable, and we care also about nature and wildlife. We firmly believe that sustainable conservation can only happen, if communities and wildlife find a way to coexist. And that is what this project is about.

The Crocodylus acutus is a species that exists from the south of the United States to the north of Perú and is one of the larger crocodile species. This impressive animal can reach lengths of 6.1 m (20 ft), weighing up to 907 kg (2,000 lb) and can live up to 70 years. One of the largest populations of Crocodylus acutus in Costa Rica can be found in the Tempisque River, in the north west of the country, in Guanacaste Province.

Along the banks of this river also live many men, women and children who are in constant contact with these giant lizards. Those are small vulnerable communities that subsist working in the sugar cane and watermelon plantations or extracting sand from the river. According to official statistics, poverty affects 23.6% of the population in Guanacaste, among then the communities along the Tempisque River.

This is one of the three EXCLUSIVE images of the "Lagarteada" that you will get as a postcard when contributing with US$ 25 to the campaign. You can also take a look at the other nice perks that we are offering to you.

PROBLEM DESCRIPTION

In the Tempisque area of Costa Rica people have always hunted crocodiles in order to eat their meat, trade their skins and use their fat, which is believed to have medicinal power (especially that of the females). Another reason why the crocodiles have been hunted is the fear of attacks and the protection of livestock. In the last two hundred years, the hunting of the crocodiles took the species to the brink of extinction.

40 years ago the costarican government prohibited hunting crocodiles and as a result the species recovered. It is by no means out of danger, but its status has changed to vulnerable, and no longer in danger of extinction. Studies are currently being done to determine whether the population is stable or not yet.

The destruction of its natural habitat, due to development, deforestation, agricultural monoculture, destruction of wetlands and river pollution, to name but a few, causes that today the crocodile population is concentrating in ever smaller territories closer to human populations. This is the reason why the relationship between local communities and crocodiles is becoming more conflictive.  There are more incidents of people being attacked by crocodiles as well as crocodiles eating livestock. Economic and recreational activities along and in the river like fishing or bathing are increasingly more dangerous. Because of the vicinity of habitats crocodiles are more visible giving an erroneous impression of overpopulation. Lack of shade along the riverbanks and less than ideal nesting habitat leads to higher temperature in the nests, causing a gender imbalance. Higher temperatures lead to more males being born, increasing the aggressiveness of the animals. Another factor negatively affecting the gender ratio appears to be the use of the hormone 17α-methyltestosterone (MT) in the large scale fish farms raising Tilapias along the river.

In our experience in working with these communities, all the crocodile attacks against humans have something in common: lack of knowledge about the animal’s behavior in the communities living closest to them, leading to poor safety measures and ever more deteriorated habitats. People often don't know basic facts about the species, like for example how to distinguish males from females or when mating and nesting seasons take place. All of this is due to lack of attention, education and communication to these communities by the Costa Rican authorities.

THE GLOBAL CHALLENGE OF OUR MODERN SOCIETIES

The human-crocodile conflict in the Tempisque River is emblematic of the larger global context. It speaks about the global challenge our modern societies confront in terms of the tension between human development and the reduction of natural areas for wildlife. It also reflects the conflict between marginal communities with their traditional way of life and modern development. When it comes to conservation measures, local communities are often not taken into consideration, rendering protection policies less effective while leaving people affected by them with fewer options. It is urgent to find a balance that allows communities, especially marginal ones, to cohabit with these impressive animals whose habitat is continually shrinking. Costa Rica has made a good effort to save the crocodiles with some noticeable effect, but we firmly believe that education and knowledge in the people of those local communities is what can help to create the necessary and sustainable balance between humans and nature.

Let this project be emblematic for the alternatives and solutions that it implies.

This beautiful crocodile-shaped ocarina, courtesy of the Chietón Morén indigenous market, is one of the perks that you will get as a very sincere “thank you” for supporting this important project. You can also take a look at the other nice and exclusive perks that we are offering to you.

THE LAGARTEADA AS THE EXEMPLIFICATION

OF THIS CONFLICT

The surroundings of the Tempisque River are a region that was inhabited by the indigenous Chorotega people long before the Spanish arrived to conquer the land. For the Chorotegas the crocodile was a sacred animal and a symbol of fertility. They used to have a big celebration during the spring equinox in which they hunted crocodiles in order to harvest their fat, meat and blood, which in their view had magical powers. During the colonization they protected their tradition with the religious syncretism that many indigenous populations used in these situations: they merged the crocodile hunting ceremony with the Holy week of the Spanish Catholic religion.

The historical records are spotty, but at some point about 200 years ago, when the Chorotegas were slowly being replaced by the "criollos", the mix between the indigenous and spanish races, a tradition started that resembles the ancestral one – the 'Lagarteada'.

The local word for the Crocodylus acutus is "lagarto", which basically means lizard, and the hunting of the lagarto is what is called the lagarteada. For decades it was an extremely cruel activity. The animal suffered because it was captured using harpoons and after the capture it was killed with knifes and its meat and fat distributed in the community. After the government prohibited crocodile hunting there has been an effort to preserve the tradition in a way that doesn´t harm the animal. The community of Ortega agreed to change several aspects of the activity, for instance the modern lagarteada no longer involves killing these great beast. After capturing the animal they bring it to the town, where a special pool has been built. The community gathers around the animal. The next morning, the same group of men bring the crocodile back to the river and set it free in the same place where it was captured, alive and without injuries. It has been done like this for many years already.

Then, in 2017 something went wrong: The animal died in captivity during the late night, causing outrage among environmentalists and conservationists. As a result, the community has been vilified, a national scandal erupted and environmental groups mobilized to prohibit the tradition. We are three months away from the next lagarteada and it´s not clear whether the activity will be carried out or not in 2018.

In a sense, the largateada tradition is at a crossroads. While some people see in this a conflict that needs to be resolved by repression and prohibitions, for us the conflict around the largateada is an educational opportunity that has the potential to benefit both, the Crocodylus acutus and the communities living near it.

OUR PROPOSAL:

TAKING ADVANTAGE OF THE CONTROVERSY

In May 2013, a group of scientist from the National University of Costa Rica conducted a research project in the Tempisque River Area. After hundreds of interviews they concluded that:

  • 80% of surveyed residents said that they had not received any information about the crocodiles and approximately the same proportion said that they were interested in environmental education activities.

  • There was an inefficient communication process between scientists, environmental educators, Ministry of Environment, wildlife managers, and those who really need the information (being the communities).

Source: “Activities That May Influence the Risk of Crocodile (Crocodylus Acutus: Reptilia: Crocodilidae) Attack to Humans in the Tempisque River Area, Guanacaste, Costa Rica. (Iván Sandoval-Hernández, Alejandro Duran-Apuy, Jacqueline Quirós-Valerio y otros)” publicado por Revista Uniciencia (http://www.revistas.una.ac.cr/index.php/uniciencia/article/view/9040)

We have being accompanying the community over the last three years. We firmly believe that there is a solution to this problem and that it has to do with awareness raising in local communities and on a national level. The key is the environmental education of affected communities and the reconstruction and protection of the habitats. Our ultimate goal is to save the crocodiles but this cannot happen without the cooperation of local communities.

An example picture from Ñuku / The photo book.

WHAT WE NEED: THE PHOTO BOOK

AND THE TRAVELING PHOTOGRAPHIC EXHIBITION

We wrote a photo book about the traditional lagarteada of the community of Ortega, with 84 exclusive images of the event of 2017, strong and beautiful images that have the power to change hearts and minds. The book's title is “Ñuku” (crocodile, in the Chorotega language) and contains the opinion of scientists, important data about the Crocodylus acutus that everybody who lives nearby the rivers needs to know, some of the history of the Chorotega tradition, points of view of the environmentalist groups and the testimony and words of the people of Ortega. This book would be an extraordinary didactic material and a powerful resource to raise awareness.

With this campaign we are planning to print at least 250 copies of the book together with 26 photographs (30" x 20") for the traveling photographic exhibition.

HOW WILL THE BOOK HELP

IN THE CONSERVATION OF THE CROCODILE?

1rst. the recognition of the value of the culture and traditions of the Ortega community is an important step to generate an alliance that allows working with them in the conservation of the crocodile. Since the community is a determining factor in the protection of the animal, only if its needs are being taken into account, can a sustainable solution be found.

2nd. the book seeks to be a bridge between the different actors of the country so that they can begin to listen to each other. It gives space to the community to express their points of view along with powerful images that allow a visceral access to the experience of the affected people. The book also contains information that will be more easily digested by the community because it is portrayed by themselves, respectful off their traditions and experience.

3rd. the book will allow us to lobby and advocacy work before government institutions, private companies and environmental groups, with the aim of the conservation of crocodile habitats.

4rth. the book is an important tool for fundraising in order to carry out the project’s medium term goals, reforestation and the expansion of natural habitats for the crocodiles in Costa Rica.

A portion of the books will be donated to affected communities, schools and local government institutions, as well as private companies and environmental organizations in the context of the educational activities planned within this project: the traveling photographic exhibitions. The rest of the books will be sold and with the profit the project will continue to be financed.

THE TARGET AUDIENCE FOR THE EXHIBITION OF THE PHOTOGRAPHS

The photographs will be displayed in the schools and colleges of those Guanacaste communities whose students reside in areas of coexistence with crocodiles (Rio Tempisque). The exhibition will be accompanied by environmental education workshops on the human-crocodile conflict that will be under the responsibility of Laura Porras, researcher and teacher of the Master's Degree program in Conservation and Wildlife Management of the International Institute for the Conservation and Management of Wildlife (ICOMVIS) and students of the Environmental Sciences career at the National University of Costa Rica. We believe that it will be easier for children and young people to feel identified and interested in the workshops if we start from images that reflect their own communities and cultural traditions.

WE WANT TO RAISE AWARENESS BUT ALSO DO SOMETHING ELSE, WITH YOU ON BOARD.

If we succeed and exceed the fund raising goal, hopefully by a large percentage, all the surplus money collected will be used in:

  • Printing more books (initially we were thinking of an edition of 500 copies).

  • Financing a reforestation program, in coordination with the School of Ortega, the International Institute for the Conservation and Management of Wildlife and asking for the technical advice of the forest nursery of the School of Forest Sciences of the National University of Costa Rica (which would also donate a first quantity of trees), in order to plant autochthonous trees in the margins of the river, to help rebuilding the nesting habitat of the Crocodylus acutus.

HOW CAN YOU CONTRIBUTE?

We already have the content of the book and the exhibition, so what we need is to design, print, reproduce and distribute the material. The approximated coast of this initial part of the project is:

Designing and printing the book (250 copies):                                              US$ 1000 + US$ 7000

Printing the Photographs for the traveling exposition (26 copies):                                 US$ 1000

Perks:                                                                                                                                                     US$ 1000

Shipping the books and perks:                                                                                                     US$ 1000

Total:                                                                                                                               US$ 11000


An example picture from Ñuku / The photo book.

WHAT DO YOU GET IN RETURN?

If you contribute with this campaign we offer you many different kinds of perks, as a very sincere “thank you” for supporting this important project.

Starting from US$ 25 you will be getting three really nice postcards of the lagarteada tradition. Those three photographs have been part of the international exhibition “ESFotoperiodismo 2015” that was traveling through El Salvador, Guatemala and Honduras during a year, with the support of the Photography Center of the Latitudes Foundation, the Cultural Center of Spain and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of El Salvador.

In the column on the side you can find out about the other great perks that we are offering to reward your generosity towards this awareness effort.

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN COLLABORATE

If you can't contribute but you want to get involved anyway, there is something else that you can do: become our ambassador. Help us to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign. Tell your friends, relatives, coworkers or classmates, talk to all the people that you know that might be interested in supporting this campaign. The more people you tell the more chances we have to reach our goal.

WHO WE ARE?

Allan Barboza-Leitón / I am a documentary photographer with focus on social causes and human rights, founder member of the Costa Rican Association of Documentary Makers and also founder of the Action Center for Human Rights. I am vegetarian and I stand up for the animal rights. I am convinced that we only can change things in a lasting way if we trust in the capability of the people to grow consciousness and provide them with the information and tools required to grow awareness. I use my camera to help this goal and I am committed to make a contribution to leave a better world in the hands of the next generations.

Gabriela Segura Umaña / I am a psychologist with experience working with different communities. I have collaborated with populations in vulnerable conditions and with groups of rural-coastal women in the Northern Pacific of Costa Rica, as well as with fishermen and farmers from the border between Costa Rica and Nicaragua. I am passionate about the histories of the everyday life of the humbled people, strongly motivated by the environmental causes and committed with the human and animal rights.
