story:
The big picture:

Each year 9 Million Metric Tonnes of plastic enters the world's oceans, drastically altering the delicate balance of marine life. Over 80% of this ocean plastic originates from land-based sources and with some Americans now unable to recycle their plastic this figure is guaranteed to only go up.

If nothing is done to combat the flow of ocean plastics into waterways and the sea by 2050 there will be more plastics in the ocean than fish. We can't let this happen!

Think we have time to sit this out? No way! Plastics take upwards of 400+ years to decompose and the current flow of plastic into the ocean will compound rapidly.

Why is this happening? 95% of Plastic ( bottles, containers, straws, etc. ) are used just once then thrown away.



This cycle needs to stop, and the answer is creating more products out of Recycled plastic and saying No to products made from new plastics. 

 

The Process

A lot goes into how we make our products & even more goes into making sure they are sustainable.

You Can Help Without giving us money

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

Share our page (Use the Share Links Above)

come by and like our Facebook page.

 

Special thanks to Precious Plastic

We could never have even begun to do this without you. 
Check out Daves open source designs for plastic recycling equipment at https://preciousplastic.com/ .

story:
(Español al final)

Short Summary                   

Niger Delta mangroves, the most biodiverse of all ecosystems and the best carbon storage available on the planet, are being destroyed.

However, there exist people willing to restore it, planting the new seedlings. Young volunteers from close villages, they have the will, but lack food to be able to work.  The goal is to plant 100,000 mangrove trees in the Stubbs Creek Forest Reserve in the south of the Akwa Ibom region. 2,000 trees have already been planted. 

One hundred volunteers are organized in a local Tropical Research Conservation Center (TRCC). Between Czech innovator myELEN.com and TRCC, we developed a donation-barter system, the Food for Mangroves Adoption System, providing meals to volunteers through targeted micro-donations. The system permits to trace every dollar - and link it to planted mangrove seedlings.

The donor finances food to hardworking mangrove saviors and receives a report on the number and placement of mangrove seedlings. 

Currently, we count with 100 young volunteers who participate in the plantation of mangroves. If we support them with food, large surfaces of mangroves will be restored. 

 

 

What We Need & What You Get

•        Every 2 EUR will translate in a meal for a volunteer - responsible for the plantation of 15 seedlings. A mangrove tree absorbs an average of 12.3  kgCO2/year for the West Africa region (Donato et al., 2011). Thus, 4 EUR will help to capture 360 kg CO2/year.

•        For 4 EUR of support, each volunteer will plant approximately 30 mangrove trees per day. 

•        If you would support 1 volunteer for 1 month of mangrove plantation, it would lead to the absorption of more than 7,400 kg CO2 per year. 

•        The purchase of meals provided for volunteers will be coordinated by TRCC and will be produced by local suppliers. The guarantor and supervisor of local operations will be TRCC.

•         The meals will be nutritive, produced locally in systems with sustainable practices. Thus, we support the virtuous circle of consumption. 

•        The information channel and coordinator of information to donors will be myELEN.com.  Every donor will be informed on the use of the donation per email / on the internet wall. 

•        Production of food for self-consumption by small farmers in rural areas of the Niger Delta will make them secure mangroves rather than exploiting them in an unsustainable way. The volunteering work will be empowered by good meals. 

 

The Impact

•         Reaching the goal of supporting 1 TRCC volunteer with 1 month of his food = 7,400 kg CO2

•         The benefitted region will be the Stubbs Creek Forest Reserve (SCFR) in Akwa Ibom State, Niger Delta Region of Nigeria in communities Eket, Esit Eket, Onna, Ibiono.

•        Restoration of mangroves will recreate habitat for fish, crustaceans, sponges, algae, mammals, aquatic birds, reptiles, and endangered species such as pygmy hippopotamus (Choeropsis liberiensis), manatees (Trichechus senegalensis), crocodiles (Crocodylus niloticus), or white-throated monkey (Cercopithecus erythrogaster) and many others. 

•        Mangroves regulate local ecosystem processes such as blue carbon sink, water depuration, and protection against hurricanes, among others. It hosts high biodiversity for being a wetland in the transition of terrestrial and oceanic ecosystems. 

•         We need to put to work a mechanism able to transform targeted micro-donations into meals - and trace them efficiently - make this a massive channel. The creation of the food adoption system on a credible and efficient level can lead to the formation of a channel of support to other organizations.  

 

 

Meet some of the volunteers

Edikan, Bassey, and Charles volunteer for the plantation of new mangroves in degraded areas of the Stubbs Creek Forest Reserve (SCFR). They work 3 days per week, Your support will encourage them to keep doing this noble action that brings development to their communities.  

Risks & Challenges

There are risks related to this reforestation project.

•        The area may be affected by tropical cyclones.

•        Political instability can affect the restoration of mangroves and can affect the local                            organization. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute with donations, but that doesn't mean they can't help. 

It would be of great help if you share this campaign on social media with your family, friends, colleagues, or anyone that has an interest in environmental and social issues. Ask folks to get the word out and make noise about our campaign.

We also need volunteers of all kinds, as well as distributors who can distribute sustainable products. Just write us to info@myelen.com and let us seek a way how can we collaborate. 

 

 

Why do we do this?

We believe that supporting the proactivity of individuals gives them a lifetime chance. We believe that the prosperity of individuals leads to the prosperity of the whole society. We believe that small amounts can make a big difference. We believe that every single one of us has the power to make a positive impact in this world.

With time being such a coveted commodity in the fight against Climate Change and the global ecological depletion, wise investments (be it time, money or skills) need to be channeled correctly for the most beneficial (sustainable) output. In line with our values, in myelen.com we offer a clear way of channeling money without bluffing or empty promises.

What is needed to recreate mangroves is just to organize a few euros for food  - isn't it a wise action to do? More so, if that could become an example for other similar actions. 

 

 

Technical / Additional Characteristics 

Type of mangrove to be planted

Red mangroves, Rhizophora, known as “ the true mangrove".  The Red mangrove (Rhizophora mangle) is the tallest of all mangrove species. It grows as high as 80 feet (25m). The wood of the trunk has a high density, making it attractive for industrial use. During the life of a Rhizophora mangle tree, the stem can reach a diameter of 20 to 50cm. It has large broad leaves grow to 5 inches (12cm) and terminate with a blunt point. The leaves are waxy, dark green above and pale green below. The trunk and limbs have grey bark that covers a dark redwood and with oblong or oval-shaped leaves. The canopy serves as a habitat for many arboreal animals, especially birds, squirrels, pottos, and monkeys.

Type of multipurpose/fruit  trees growing in mangrove areas

Kola nut (Cola nitida), bitter cola (Garcinia kola), wild mango (Irvingia gabonensis), african breadfruit (Treculia africana), oil bean tree (Pentaclethra macrophyllaI) star apple (Chrysophyllum albidum), african pear, (Dacryodes edulis) and locust bean tree (Paria clappertoniana).

Density and distribution of plantation of mangrove and multipurpose trees

• 200 mangroves trees per hectare for mangroves

• 100 trees per hectare for the multi-purpose/fruit trees.

The life cycle of mangrove 
The mangrove grows into tall trees within two to three years, mainly propagated by propagules. The flowers are thought to be self-pollinated or wind-pollinated. Following the pollination, mangrove seeds undergo continuous development from flower to germinated seedling when it is still attached to the mangrove tree. The seedlings or propagules can then be collected for nursery and transplanting.

Reforestation plan

The objective is 100,000 mangrove stands and 20,000 multipurpose trees. The entire size of the forest area is 10,000 hectares. The reforestation will mainly be carried out at highly degraded spots within the forest (~700 hectares ). Less degraded portions will be let for natural succession. 

The project will help to conserve the entire forest area, preventing it from further degradation. The plot lies between latitudes 4032’ N and 40 38’N and longitudes 7054’E and 8018’E and is located at the Southern end of the Akwa Ibom State, stretching from Enwang to James Town. It forms a buffer zone between the Atlantic coast and the Akwa Ibom State mainland. The vegetation is a mosaic of a lowland rain forest and mangrove swamp forest. In Akwa Ibom State, Stubbs Creek represents the only remaining natural coastal swamp forest of any significant size  (Ohimain, 2003; Omo-Irabor et al., 2011). There are 39 villages or settlements in the four surrounding communities (Eket, Esit Eket, Ibeno, and Mbo ) that derive many benefits from the forest. 

 

Thank you very much for your attention, get to know us better here:

www.myelen.com

www.tropicalconservationcentre.org

www.facebook.com/myelencom

 

(ESPAÑOL)

Resumen

Los manglares del Delta del Níger, uno de los ecosistemas más biodiversos y el mejor almacén de carbono disponible en el planeta, está siendo destruido.

Sin embargo, existen personas dispuestas a restaurarlo plantando nuevas semillas. Jóvenes voluntarios de poblados cercanos que tienen la voluntad, pero falta de alimento suficiente para poder trabajar plenamente. La meta es plantar 100,000 manglares en la Reserva Forestal Stubbs Creek en el sur de la región de Akwa Ibom. De los cuales, 2,000 manglares ya han sido plantados.

Cien voluntarios son organizados por el Tropical Research Conservation Center (TRCC, por sus siglas en inglés). Entre el innovador Checo myELEN.com y el TRCC, desarrollamos un sistema de donación-trueque, el Sistema de Adopción de Alimentos para Manglares. Para proveer de alimento a los voluntarios a través de micro donaciones dirigidas. El sistema permite seguir cada euro – y ligarlo a plántulas de manglar plantadas. 

El donante financiará alimentos para rescatistas de manglar muy trabajadores, y recibirán un reporte del número y la ubicación de las plántulas de manglar.

Actualmente, contamos con 100 voluntarios jóvenes que participan en la plantación de manglares. Si los apoyamos con alimentos, se restaurarán grandes superficies de manglar.

 

¿Qué necesitamos y qué obtendrás?

•        Cada 2 EUR se traducirán en una comida para un voluntario – responsable por la instalación de 15 plántulas. Un manglar absorbe un promedio de 12.3 kgCO2/año para la región de África del Oeste (Donato et al., 2011). Entonces, 4 EUR ayudarán a captar 360 kg CO2/año.

•        Por 4 EUR de apoyo, cada voluntario plantará aproximadamente 30 plántulas de manglar por día de trabajo

•       Si apoyas 1 voluntario por 1 mes de plantación de manglares, conducirá a la absorción de más de 7,400 kg CO2 anuales.

•        La compra de alimentos para los voluntarios será coordinada por el TRCC y será producida por proveedores locales. El garante y supervisor de las operaciones locales será el TRCC.

•         Los alimentos serán nutritivos, producidos en sistemas locales con prácticas sustentables. Por lo que apoyaremos un círculo virtuoso de consumo.

•        El canal de información y coordinación de comunicación con los donantes será myELEN.com. Cada donante será informado del uso de donativos por correo / en la pared de la página.

•        La producción de alimentos para auto consumo por pequeños productores en áreas rurales del Delta del Níger, hará que protejan los manglares en vez de explotarlos. El trabajo voluntario será fortalecido por buenas comidas.

                               

 

El impacto

•         Apoyando a 1 voluntario del TRCC con un mes de alimentación se secuestrará potencialmente 7,400 kg CO2 al año

•         La región beneficiada será la Reserva Forestal Stubbs Creek en el estado de Akwa Ibom, región Delta del Níger en las comunidades Eket, Esit Eket, Onna, Ibiono en Nigeria.

•        La restauración de manglares recreará hábitat para peces, crustáceos, esponjas, algas, mamíferos, aves acuáticas, reptiles, y especies amenazadas como el hipopótamo pigmeo (Choeropsis liberiensis), manatíes (Trichechus senegalensis), cocodrilos (Crocodylus niloticus), monos cuello blanco (Cercopithecus erythrogaster) y muchos otros. 

•        Los manglares regulan ciclos de materia y energía como sumideros de carbono azul, tratamiento de agua, protección contra huracanes, entre otros. Acoge una alta biodiversidad por ser un humedal transitorio entre ecosistemas terrestres y oceánicos.

•         Necesitamos poner a trabajar un mecanismo capaz de transformar micro donaciones dirigidas en alimentos – seguirlos eficientemente – y hacerlo un canal masivo. La creación del sistema de adopción de alimentos en un nivel creíble y eficiente puede llevar a la formación de canales de apoyo para otras organizaciones.

 

Conoce a algunos de los voluntarios

Edikan, Bassey, y Charles hacen voluntariado plantando manglares en zonas dañadas de la Reserva Forestal Stubbs Creek (SCFR). Trabajan 3 días a la semana, Tu apoyo los motivará a que continuen haciendo ésta noble acción, the genera desarrollo para sus comunidades.

Riesgos y retos

Existen riesgos relacionados a este Proyecto de reforestación.

•        El área puede ser afectada por ciclones tropicales.

•        La inestabilidad política puede afectar la restauración de manglares y puede afectar la organización local.

 

Otras formas en las que puedes ayudar

Algunas personas simplemente no pueden contribuir con dinero, pero no significa que no puedan ayudar.

Sería también de gran ayuda que compartas esta campaña en tus redes sociales, con tu familia, amigos, colegas, o cualquier persona que tenga interés en asuntos ambientales y sociales. Pide a las personas que pasen la voz y hagan ruido acerca de esta campaña. 

También necesitamos voluntarios de todos los tipos, además de distribuidores que puedan mover productos sustentables. Solo escríbenos a info@myelen.com y podemos encontrar una forma en la que podemos colaborar.

 

 

 ¿Por qué hacemos esto?

Creemos que apoyar la proactividad de los individuos les da una oportunidad de por vida. Además de pensar que la prosperidad de los individuos va unida a la de toda la sociedad. También creemos que pequeñas cantidades pueden marcar una gran diferencia y que cada uno de nosotros tiene el poder de tener un impacto positivo en este mundo.

El tiempo es una mercancía muy codiciada en la lucha contra el Cambio Climático y la debacle ecológica global. Las inversiones inteligentes (ya sea de tiempo, dinero o habilidades) deben canalizarse correctamente para obtener una producción más beneficiosa (sustentable). En línea con nuestros valores, en myelen.com ofrecemos una forma clara canalizar dinero sin faroles ni promesas vacías.

Lo que se necesita para restaurar los manglares es sólo reunir unos cuantos euros para alimentos - ¿no es esta una acción inteligente por hacer? Más aún, si eso pudiera convertirse en un ejemplo para otras acciones similares.

 

Características adicionales / técnicas 

Tipo de manglar a plantar

Manglares rojos, Rhizophora, conocido como "el manglar verdadero".  El manglar rojo (Rhizophora) es el más grande de todas las especies de manglares. Crece hasta 80 pies (25m) y la madera del tronco tiene una alta densidad, por lo que es atractiva para el uso industrial y para captura de CO2.

Durante la vida de un árbol de Rhizophora, el tallo puede alcanzar un diámetro de 20 a 50cm. Tiene grandes hojas anchas crecen hasta 5 pulgadas (12cm), terminan en punta redonda y son hojas brillantes, de color verde oscuro por encima y verde pálido por debajo. El tronco y las extremidades tienen una corteza gris que cubre una madera roja oscura y con hojas oblongas u ovaladas. La cubierta sirve de hábitat para muchos animales arbóreos, especialmente aves, ardillas, pottos (lémures africanos) y monos.

Tipo de árboles multipropósitos/frutales que crecen en zonas de manglares

Nuez de cola (Cola nitida), cola amarga (Garcinia kola), mango silvestre (Irvingia gabonensis), fruta de pan africana (Treculia africana), árbol de aceite de haba (Pentaclethra macrophyllal) manzana estrellada (Chrysophyllum albidum), pera africana, (Dacryodes edulis) y la algarroba africana (Parkia clappertoniana).
 

Densidad y distribución de plantaciones de manglares y árboles frutales

  • 200 manglares por hectárea para la zona de manglares
  • 100 árboles por hectárea para la zona de los árboles multiusos/frutales.

Propagación y manejo de manglares

El manglar rojo crece en árboles grandes entre dos a tres años. Los manglares se propagan principalmente por propágulos y semillas. Las flores se cree que son auto polinizadas o polinizadas por el viento. Después de la polinización, los propágulos de los manglares experimentan un desarrollo continuo de flor a plántula germinada. Las plántulas o propágulos se pueden después llevar al vivero para después ser trasplantadas a las zonas de reforestación.

Plan de reforestación

El objetivo es la plantación de 100.000 manglares y 20.000 árboles siendo el tamaño total de la superficie forestal de 10.000 hectáreas. La reforestación se llevará a cabo principalmente en lugares muy desgastados dentro del bosque (700 hectáreas aproximadamente).

Las porciones menos degradadas se dejarán para su restauración por sucesión ecológica. El proyecto ayudará a conservar toda la superficie forestal, evitando una mayor degradación. El área de reforestación está situada entre las latitudes 4032' N y 40 38'N y las longitudes 7054'E y 8018'E, y se encuentra en el extremo sur del estado de Akwa Ibom, que se extiende desde Enwang hasta James Town.

Forma una zona de amortiguamiento entre la costa atlántica y ecosistemas de tierra firme. La vegetación es un mosaico de una selva tropical de tierras bajas y un bosque de pantanos de manglares. En el estado de Akwa Ibom, Stubbs Creek representa el único bosque de pantanos costeros naturales de tamaño significativo restante (Ohimain, 2003; Omo-Irabor et al., 2011). Hay 39 aldeas o asentamientos en las cuatro comunidades circundantes (Eket, Esit Eket, Ibeno y Mbo) que obtienen muchos beneficios del bosque.

Muchas gracias por tu atención, conócenos mejor aquí:

www.myelen.com/es

www.tropicalconservationcentre.org

www.facebook.com/myelencom
story_txt:
(Español al final)
Short Summary                   
Niger Delta mangroves, the most biodiverse of all ecosystems and the best carbon storage available on the planet, are being destroyed.

However, there exist people willing to restore it, planting the new seedlings. Young volunteers from close villages, they have the will, but lack food to be able to work.  The goal is to plant 100,000 mangrove trees in the Stubbs Creek Forest Reserve in the south of the Akwa Ibom region. 2,000 trees have already been planted. 
One hundred volunteers are organized in a local Tropical Research Conservation Center (TRCC). Between Czech innovator myELEN.com and TRCC, we developed a donation-barter system, the Food for Mangroves Adoption System, providing meals to volunteers through targeted micro-donations. The system permits to trace every dollar - and link it to planted mangrove seedlings.
The donor finances food to hardworking mangrove saviors and receives a report on the number and placement of mangrove seedlings. Currently, we count with 100 young volunteers who participate in the plantation of mangroves. If we support them with food, large surfaces of mangroves will be restored. 
 


 
What We Need & What You Get
•        Every 2 EUR will translate in a meal for a volunteer - responsible for the plantation of 15 seedlings. A mangrove tree absorbs an average of 12.3  kgCO2/year for the West Africa region (Donato et al., 2011). Thus, 4 EUR will help to capture 360 kg CO2/year.
•        For 4 EUR of support, each volunteer will plant approximately 30 mangrove trees per day. 
•        If you would support 1 volunteer for 1 month of mangrove plantation, it would lead to the absorption of more than 7,400 kg CO2 per year. 
•        The purchase of meals provided for volunteers will be coordinated by TRCC and will be produced by local suppliers. The guarantor and supervisor of local operations will be TRCC.
•         The meals will be nutritive, produced locally in systems with sustainable practices. Thus, we support the virtuous circle of consumption. 
•        The information channel and coordinator of information to donors will be myELEN.com.  Every donor will be informed on the use of the donation per email / on the internet wall. 
•        Production of food for self-consumption by small farmers in rural areas of the Niger Delta will make them secure mangroves rather than exploiting them in an unsustainable way. The volunteering work will be empowered by good meals. 

 

The Impact
•         Reaching the goal of supporting 1 TRCC volunteer with 1 month of his food = 7,400 kg CO2
•         The benefitted region will be the Stubbs Creek Forest Reserve (SCFR) in Akwa Ibom State, Niger Delta Region of Nigeria in communities Eket, Esit Eket, Onna, Ibiono.
•        Restoration of mangroves will recreate habitat for fish, crustaceans, sponges, algae, mammals, aquatic birds, reptiles, and endangered species such as pygmy hippopotamus (Choeropsis liberiensis), manatees (Trichechus senegalensis), crocodiles (Crocodylus niloticus), or white-throated monkey (Cercopithecus erythrogaster) and many others. 
•        Mangroves regulate local ecosystem processes such as blue carbon sink, water depuration, and protection against hurricanes, among others. It hosts high biodiversity for being a wetland in the transition of terrestrial and oceanic ecosystems. 
•         We need to put to work a mechanism able to transform targeted micro-donations into meals - and trace them efficiently - make this a massive channel. The creation of the food adoption system on a credible and efficient level can lead to the formation of a channel of support to other organizations.  
 


 
Meet some of the volunteers

Edikan, Bassey, and Charles volunteer for the plantation of new mangroves in degraded areas of the Stubbs Creek Forest Reserve (SCFR). They work 3 days per week, Your support will encourage them to keep doing this noble action that brings development to their communities.  
Risks & Challenges
There are risks related to this reforestation project.
•        The area may be affected by tropical cyclones.
•        Political instability can affect the restoration of mangroves and can affect the local                            organization. 
 
Other Ways You Can Help
Some people just can't contribute with donations, but that doesn't mean they can't help. 
It would be of great help if you share this campaign on social media with your family, friends, colleagues, or anyone that has an interest in environmental and social issues. Ask folks to get the word out and make noise about our campaign.
We also need volunteers of all kinds, as well as distributors who can distribute sustainable products. Just write us to info@myelen.com and let us seek a way how can we collaborate. 
 

 
Why do we do this?
We believe that supporting the proactivity of individuals gives them a lifetime chance. We believe that the prosperity of individuals leads to the prosperity of the whole society. We believe that small amounts can make a big difference. We believe that every single one of us has the power to make a positive impact in this world.
With time being such a coveted commodity in the fight against Climate Change and the global ecological depletion, wise investments (be it time, money or skills) need to be channeled correctly for the most beneficial (sustainable) output. In line with our values, in myelen.com we offer a clear way of channeling money without bluffing or empty promises.
What is needed to recreate mangroves is just to organize a few euros for food  - isn't it a wise action to do? More so, if that could become an example for other similar actions. 
 

 
Technical / Additional Characteristics 

Type of mangrove to be planted
Red mangroves, Rhizophora, known as “ the true mangrove".  The Red mangrove (Rhizophora mangle) is the tallest of all mangrove species. It grows as high as 80 feet (25m). The wood of the trunk has a high density, making it attractive for industrial use. During the life of a Rhizophora mangle tree, the stem can reach a diameter of 20 to 50cm. It has large broad leaves grow to 5 inches (12cm) and terminate with a blunt point. The leaves are waxy, dark green above and pale green below. The trunk and limbs have grey bark that covers a dark redwood and with oblong or oval-shaped leaves. The canopy serves as a habitat for many arboreal animals, especially birds, squirrels, pottos, and monkeys.
Type of multipurpose/fruit  trees growing in mangrove areas
Kola nut (Cola nitida), bitter cola (Garcinia kola), wild mango (Irvingia gabonensis), african breadfruit (Treculia africana), oil bean tree (Pentaclethra macrophyllaI) star apple (Chrysophyllum albidum), african pear, (Dacryodes edulis) and locust bean tree (Paria clappertoniana).Density and distribution of plantation of mangrove and multipurpose trees
• 200 mangroves trees per hectare for mangroves
• 100 trees per hectare for the multi-purpose/fruit trees.
The life cycle of mangrove The mangrove grows into tall trees within two to three years, mainly propagated by propagules. The flowers are thought to be self-pollinated or wind-pollinated. Following the pollination, mangrove seeds undergo continuous development from flower to germinated seedling when it is still attached to the mangrove tree. The seedlings or propagules can then be collected for nursery and transplanting.
Reforestation plan
The objective is 100,000 mangrove stands and 20,000 multipurpose trees. The entire size of the forest area is 10,000 hectares. The reforestation will mainly be carried out at highly degraded spots within the forest (~700 hectares ). Less degraded portions will be let for natural succession. 
The project will help to conserve the entire forest area, preventing it from further degradation. The plot lies between latitudes 4032’ N and 40 38’N and longitudes 7054’E and 8018’E and is located at the Southern end of the Akwa Ibom State, stretching from Enwang to James Town. It forms a buffer zone between the Atlantic coast and the Akwa Ibom State mainland. The vegetation is a mosaic of a lowland rain forest and mangrove swamp forest. In Akwa Ibom State, Stubbs Creek represents the only remaining natural coastal swamp forest of any significant size  (Ohimain, 2003; Omo-Irabor et al., 2011). There are 39 villages or settlements in the four surrounding communities (Eket, Esit Eket, Ibeno, and Mbo ) that derive many benefits from the forest. 

 
Thank you very much for your attention, get to know us better here:
www.myelen.com
www.tropicalconservationcentre.org
www.facebook.com/myelencom
 

(ESPAÑOL)
Resumen
Los manglares del Delta del Níger, uno de los ecosistemas más biodiversos y el mejor almacén de carbono disponible en el planeta, está siendo destruido.

Sin embargo, existen personas dispuestas a restaurarlo plantando nuevas semillas. Jóvenes voluntarios de poblados cercanos que tienen la voluntad, pero falta de alimento suficiente para poder trabajar plenamente. La meta es plantar 100,000 manglares en la Reserva Forestal Stubbs Creek en el sur de la región de Akwa Ibom. De los cuales, 2,000 manglares ya han sido plantados.
Cien voluntarios son organizados por el Tropical Research Conservation Center (TRCC, por sus siglas en inglés). Entre el innovador Checo myELEN.com y el TRCC, desarrollamos un sistema de donación-trueque, el Sistema de Adopción de Alimentos para Manglares. Para proveer de alimento a los voluntarios a través de micro donaciones dirigidas. El sistema permite seguir cada euro – y ligarlo a plántulas de manglar plantadas. 
El donante financiará alimentos para rescatistas de manglar muy trabajadores, y recibirán un reporte del número y la ubicación de las plántulas de manglar.
Actualmente, contamos con 100 voluntarios jóvenes que participan en la plantación de manglares. Si los apoyamos con alimentos, se restaurarán grandes superficies de manglar.



 
¿Qué necesitamos y qué obtendrás?
•        Cada 2 EUR se traducirán en una comida para un voluntario – responsable por la instalación de 15 plántulas. Un manglar absorbe un promedio de 12.3 kgCO2/año para la región de África del Oeste (Donato et al., 2011). Entonces, 4 EUR ayudarán a captar 360 kg CO2/año.
•        Por 4 EUR de apoyo, cada voluntario plantará aproximadamente 30 plántulas de manglar por día de trabajo
•       Si apoyas 1 voluntario por 1 mes de plantación de manglares, conducirá a la absorción de más de 7,400 kg CO2 anuales.
•        La compra de alimentos para los voluntarios será coordinada por el TRCC y será producida por proveedores locales. El garante y supervisor de las operaciones locales será el TRCC.
•         Los alimentos serán nutritivos, producidos en sistemas locales con prácticas sustentables. Por lo que apoyaremos un círculo virtuoso de consumo.
•        El canal de información y coordinación de comunicación con los donantes será myELEN.com. Cada donante será informado del uso de donativos por correo / en la pared de la página.
•        La producción de alimentos para auto consumo por pequeños productores en áreas rurales del Delta del Níger, hará que protejan los manglares en vez de explotarlos. El trabajo voluntario será fortalecido por buenas comidas.
                               
 


El impacto
•         Apoyando a 1 voluntario del TRCC con un mes de alimentación se secuestrará potencialmente 7,400 kg CO2 al año
•         La región beneficiada será la Reserva Forestal Stubbs Creek en el estado de Akwa Ibom, región Delta del Níger en las comunidades Eket, Esit Eket, Onna, Ibiono en Nigeria.
•        La restauración de manglares recreará hábitat para peces, crustáceos, esponjas, algas, mamíferos, aves acuáticas, reptiles, y especies amenazadas como el hipopótamo pigmeo (Choeropsis liberiensis), manatíes (Trichechus senegalensis), cocodrilos (Crocodylus niloticus), monos cuello blanco (Cercopithecus erythrogaster) y muchos otros. 
•        Los manglares regulan ciclos de materia y energía como sumideros de carbono azul, tratamiento de agua, protección contra huracanes, entre otros. Acoge una alta biodiversidad por ser un humedal transitorio entre ecosistemas terrestres y oceánicos.
•         Necesitamos poner a trabajar un mecanismo capaz de transformar micro donaciones dirigidas en alimentos – seguirlos eficientemente – y hacerlo un canal masivo. La creación del sistema de adopción de alimentos en un nivel creíble y eficiente puede llevar a la formación de canales de apoyo para otras organizaciones.



 
Conoce a algunos de los voluntarios

Edikan, Bassey, y Charles hacen voluntariado plantando manglares en zonas dañadas de la Reserva Forestal Stubbs Creek (SCFR). Trabajan 3 días a la semana, Tu apoyo los motivará a que continuen haciendo ésta noble acción, the genera desarrollo para sus comunidades.
Riesgos y retos
Existen riesgos relacionados a este Proyecto de reforestación.
•        El área puede ser afectada por ciclones tropicales.
•        La inestabilidad política puede afectar la restauración de manglares y puede afectar la organización local.
 
Otras formas en las que puedes ayudar
Algunas personas simplemente no pueden contribuir con dinero, pero no significa que no puedan ayudar.
Sería también de gran ayuda que compartas esta campaña en tus redes sociales, con tu familia, amigos, colegas, o cualquier persona que tenga interés en asuntos ambientales y sociales. Pide a las personas que pasen la voz y hagan ruido acerca de esta campaña. 
También necesitamos voluntarios de todos los tipos, además de distribuidores que puedan mover productos sustentables. Solo escríbenos a info@myelen.com y podemos encontrar una forma en la que podemos colaborar.
 

 
 ¿Por qué hacemos esto?
Creemos que apoyar la proactividad de los individuos les da una oportunidad de por vida. Además de pensar que la prosperidad de los individuos va unida a la de toda la sociedad. También creemos que pequeñas cantidades pueden marcar una gran diferencia y que cada uno de nosotros tiene el poder de tener un impacto positivo en este mundo.
El tiempo es una mercancía muy codiciada en la lucha contra el Cambio Climático y la debacle ecológica global. Las inversiones inteligentes (ya sea de tiempo, dinero o habilidades) deben canalizarse correctamente para obtener una producción más beneficiosa (sustentable). En línea con nuestros valores, en myelen.com ofrecemos una forma clara canalizar dinero sin faroles ni promesas vacías.
Lo que se necesita para restaurar los manglares es sólo reunir unos cuantos euros para alimentos - ¿no es esta una acción inteligente por hacer? Más aún, si eso pudiera convertirse en un ejemplo para otras acciones similares.

 
Características adicionales / técnicas 


Tipo de manglar a plantar 
Manglares rojos, Rhizophora, conocido como "el manglar verdadero".  El manglar rojo (Rhizophora) es el más grande de todas las especies de manglares. Crece hasta 80 pies (25m) y la madera del tronco tiene una alta densidad, por lo que es atractiva para el uso industrial y para captura de CO2.
Durante la vida de un árbol de Rhizophora, el tallo puede alcanzar un diámetro de 20 a 50cm. Tiene grandes hojas anchas crecen hasta 5 pulgadas (12cm), terminan en punta redonda y son hojas brillantes, de color verde oscuro por encima y verde pálido por debajo. El tronco y las extremidades tienen una corteza gris que cubre una madera roja oscura y con hojas oblongas u ovaladas. La cubierta sirve de hábitat para muchos animales arbóreos, especialmente aves, ardillas, pottos (lémures africanos) y monos.
Tipo de árboles multipropósitos/frutales que crecen en zonas de manglares 
Nuez de cola (Cola nitida), cola amarga (Garcinia kola), mango silvestre (Irvingia gabonensis), fruta de pan africana (Treculia africana), árbol de aceite de haba (Pentaclethra macrophyllal) manzana estrellada (Chrysophyllum albidum), pera africana, (Dacryodes edulis) y la algarroba africana (Parkia clappertoniana). 
Densidad y distribución de plantaciones de manglares y árboles frutales

200 manglares por hectárea para la zona de manglares
100 árboles por hectárea para la zona de los árboles multiusos/frutales.

Propagación y manejo de manglares 
El manglar rojo crece en árboles grandes entre dos a tres años. Los manglares se propagan principalmente por propágulos y semillas. Las flores se cree que son auto polinizadas o polinizadas por el viento. Después de la polinización, los propágulos de los manglares experimentan un desarrollo continuo de flor a plántula germinada. Las plántulas o propágulos se pueden después llevar al vivero para después ser trasplantadas a las zonas de reforestación.
Plan de reforestación
El objetivo es la plantación de 100.000 manglares y 20.000 árboles siendo el tamaño total de la superficie forestal de 10.000 hectáreas. La reforestación se llevará a cabo principalmente en lugares muy desgastados dentro del bosque (700 hectáreas aproximadamente).
Las porciones menos degradadas se dejarán para su restauración por sucesión ecológica. El proyecto ayudará a conservar toda la superficie forestal, evitando una mayor degradación. El área de reforestación está situada entre las latitudes 4032' N y 40 38'N y las longitudes 7054'E y 8018'E, y se encuentra en el extremo sur del estado de Akwa Ibom, que se extiende desde Enwang hasta James Town.
Forma una zona de amortiguamiento entre la costa atlántica y ecosistemas de tierra firme. La vegetación es un mosaico de una selva tropical de tierras bajas y un bosque de pantanos de manglares. En el estado de Akwa Ibom, Stubbs Creek representa el único bosque de pantanos costeros naturales de tamaño significativo restante (Ohimain, 2003; Omo-Irabor et al., 2011). Hay 39 aldeas o asentamientos en las cuatro comunidades circundantes (Eket, Esit Eket, Ibeno y Mbo) que obtienen muchos beneficios del bosque.

Muchas gracias por tu atención, conócenos mejor aquí:
www.myelen.com/es
www.tropicalconservationcentre.org
www.facebook.com/myelencom

story:
73 is a film collective of artists from all corners of Europe, intent on contributing to further the arts, film and natural world. The Croatia Borealis is a science and cultural research expedition, initiated in 2016 by the Cultural Encounters Association. This project is a collaboration with the University of Zagreb, and has received a letter of support from Croatian President Kolinda Grabar-Kitarović (see project images)

We need your help to document and create films from this expedition, to share with all of you, to the benefit of all of us and our planet.

This project, a modern naval expedition is an exploration of consciousness and ecological awareness, striving to the profound redefinition of the human civilization values that we all stand, work and live upon. We're a 21st century crew of innovation and inspiration; explorers, scientists and artists. 

With science, whose role is to provide firm facts on which the global policies will be based upon, art is the culmination of all the awareness, research and pursuits distilled into the symbolic embodiments, beyond-logic communication and higher dimensional creations set to engender the emotions in those who perceive it.

This project is the embodiment of the new civilizational momentum and its consonants: science and culture, which have to unite, attune in collaborative efforts to address this issue and seek the better path along with this right course of history towards the reinvention our economy. Ability to adapt and procreate the sustainable, green-growth oriented, equity based economic order, which is becoming the new standard for better redistribution of resources, is becoming both short and long term global priority.

 

THE PROJECT GOALS ARE

- To conduct scientific research and artistic projects within a multicultural and multidisciplinary platform

- To engage diverse stakeholders in conversation about global and local problems and possible solutions to climate, environmental and other changes happening in the world

- To raise awareness about the global and local climate, environmental and other problems and their possible solutions through the documentaries and exhibitions about the project

 

THE PROJECT VISION

- Continuously contribute to finding the answers and solutions to global and local problems by promoting knowledge, scientific discoveries, culture and art

 

THE EXPEDITION

The expedition will sail out of Vancouver Island, Canada and follow the Pacific coast north, pass through the Bering Pass and sail around Alaska towards the Northwest Passage. Due to climate change and global heating the passage is opened for sailing, and Atlantic can be reached during the summertime. We will sail through the Northwest territory, Yukon, Nunavut and Quebec, followed by Newfoundland, Labrador and Greenland. The journey is planned to start on June 1, 2017 and will be completed approximately within one hundred days. The second part of the journey will start from Iceland in June, 2018 and go along the coast of the UK, through Scandinavia to St. Petersburg, down the Volga River through Moscow and continuing as far as the Black Sea reaching the waters of the Mediterranean Sea and the Adriatic, finally completing the journey in Split, Croatia. Due to financial and logistical requirements of the project and the internal decision making processes of our partners and sponsors it is possible that the start date of the expedition will be pushed for one year.

Studying some of the most ecologically delicate, and yet not thoroughly explored, areas of the world offers a possibility to produce relevant scientific data. This route has also been an endless inspiration for many different artists in many different fields of art. Candidates from diverse fields of natural and social sciences such as ecology, oceanography, biology, geography, geology, meteorology, astronomy, anthropology, sociology, economics, law, and fine arts will be encouraged to apply for residencies through the process and merits set by our academic team.

During the course of the expedition the project will reconcile within itself internally and externally in interaction with diverse stakeholders. A substantial emphasis in the project will be placed on the intercultural exchange and learning from the native communities en route. Establishing a dialogue and learning more about their diverse cultures, experiences in treating the environment and sustainable living will be an invaluable asset to this project. We will learn and work together with their scientific, cultural, government and non governmental establishments in search for solutions to pressing local and global issues. A ship, the platform for this expedition, will be acquired and improved with sustainable and renewable technologies, adequately equipped with several laboratories and research equipment needed for storing and processing of the gathered materials and data during the course of the journey.

The project is currently in the phase of communication with international universities and institutions, seeking partnerships and gathering feedback about the specific research and work that will be undertaken during the course of this expedition. So far we have received a positive letter of engagement from Canadian and Icelandic universities. The communication process is continuous and will further include more countries and institutions in the project as the time goes by. Our intention is to seek support form the EU and other countries on the expedition route, while including their scientific and artistic communities as well as those from the countries beyond the expedition route.

 

AFTER THE EXPEDITION

The scientists and artists in residencies will continue their work in their home countries and institutions after their residencies. All scientific research and discoveries made during the project will be eventually published and made available to the public. Along with the scientists and their research, resident artists on board will work on fine-art creations, ranging from photography, paintings, music, literature to experimental or performing arts under a time-lined schedule eventually designated to a finale-exposé, an exhibition potent for regional and global audiences, from physical to virtual platforms, transducing ingenuity of inspirations from the areas that the expedition will explore.

The film series will be perhaps the most far-reaching end product of this project. Produced by a professional film crew on board, equipped with top tier visual technology and with the approval of one of the most influential documentary selectors in Croatia, Mr. Đelo Hadžiselimović. Detailed scenery of the expedition, cultural, geographical, and ecological diversities will portrait the current state of the expedition route. Entertaining the lively atmosphere of the crew’s journey will give the films a narrative of an organic story about how the team grows together as the journey goes by. The emotions of the filmed participants, their thoughts, work and reactions will be inscripted and then moulded into a film series which will converge all of the above elements into key proactive statements which will provide its viewers with a valuable asset to take back home. Ultimately inspiring and encouraging the audience to become the awaken citizens of the world, appealing to rethink their current interaction with the environment and its consequences, inspiring to act and live consciously and better aligning their life with the universal values that this project promotes.

This is where you come in; the international community. We need at least 50 000 USD to buy everything from drones to cameras with high-quality lenses and protective gear for the equipment. WITHOUT THIS THE PROJECT WON'T BE DOCUMENTED.

HELP US GET THE WORD OUT AND MAKE SOME NOISE ABOUT THIS EXPEDITION AND OUR HOPE TO FILM IT.

 

 - share this campaign wherever you can -


ABOUT US

The Cultural Encounters Association was founded in 2004 in Zagreb, Croatia under the name Cultural Spectrum, and from 2015 has its present name. Currently it has over 500 members in record. Some of them are the Nobel laureates and Oscar winners, while others are Croatian scientists, artists and intellectuals.
As its name states, the association also promotes international encounters between Croatia and the world culture through many initiatives, projects, exhibitions and various social events. The association is involved in presenting and promoting the work from many different areas of culture and arts, ranging from literature and fine arts to gastronomy and enology. In addition to awarding scholarships to young talented Croatian artists, the association also actively participates in charity work, both in Croatia and internationally. Among other projects, our members fundraised for the Fukushima disaster in 2011 in which case the sum was later donated to the Japan embassy in Croatia.
Draško Romac, the president of the association, has a history of adventures of his own. Amidst traveling through the North American, European and Middle East roadways, the Leut project should be mentioned, as it involved a 7,5 meters long, 19th century Croatian fishing boat, which Draško refurbished and sailed through the European seas, rivers and channels between 2010 and 2012.

73collective is a film production company working with clients in everything from arts and music, to fashion and technology. Founded in 2011, we’re based in Copenhagen, New York and Zagreb - where we're always developing our own artistic practice with personal projects, focusing on fiction and documentary filmmaking. The last five years we have made about 20 short films and documentaries, across four continents (Europe, North America, Africa and Asia), 30 music videos, live sessions, live events, commercial content, in addition to projects in other formats; museum and gallery exhibitions, composing music, releasing photo books and working with cinematic Virtual Reality experiences. We've screened several music videos at CPH PIX, been selected as residents of CPH DOX 2015' VR Workshop and made short films and documentaries nominated at festivals ranging from Message to Man in St. Petersburg to Doclisboa in Portugal, with "Shadow Fighters" (dir. Josefine Gervang Heimburger) winning 'Best East African Documentary' at Zanzibar International Film Festival 2015.

 

Every contribution is welcome and perks range from a heartly thank you to joining the expedition ship!
 


NA HRVATSKOM (in Croatian):

Ovaj  projekt,  moderna  pomorska  ekspedicija,  reinvencija  je  davnih  aspiracija  s  ciljem  istraživanja  ekološke  osviještenosti  i  ljudske  svijesti,  s  težnjom  ka  temeljnoj  redefiniciji  civilizacijskih  vrijednosti  koje  zastupamo,  na  njima  radimo  i  živimo.  Modernu  posadu  21.  stoljeća  čini  vojska  inovacije  i  inspiracije, istraživači, znanstvenici i umjetnici.

U vrijeme kada lokalne klimatske promjene  i zagađenje okoliša postaju evidentni dokazi  globalnog stanja, ovaj projekt ulazi upravo u  tu  stvarnost  potičući  znanstvena  istraživanja  i  otkrića,  odnosno  sakupljajući  podatke  nužnih  za  donošenje  dugoročnih  globalnih  regulativa,  koje  su  prijeko  potrebne.  Kako  bi  s kraja ove ere i ruba na kojem se trenutno nalazimo, kojeg znanstvenici nazivaju šestom krizom izumiranja krenuli naprijed prema četvrtoj  industrijskoj revoluciji vraćanje te ponovno uspostavljanje ravnoteže između ljudskog egzistencijalnog traga i okoliša, biosfere i klimatskih  promjena, suštinski je imperativ našega doba.
Uz  znanost,  koja  je  tu  da  nam  osigura  čvrste činjenice na kojima će se zasnivati  globalni procesi odlučivanja, umjetnost  je kulminacija ljudske svijesti, istraživanja i stremljenja, pretočena u simbolička  utjelovljenja,  ne  uvijek  nužno  logične  oblike  komunikacije  te  više  dimenzionalne  kreacije  koje  imaju  sposobnost  izazivati emocije.

Ovaj  projekt  utjelovljenje  je  novog  civilizacijskog  trenutka  i  njegovih  paradigmi  znanosti,  kulture  i  umjetnosti,  koje je potrebno ujediniti te zajedničkim  naporima  uskladiti  kako  bi  se  riješili problemi i pronašao bolji put prema  reinvenciji našeg  sustava  vrijednosti. Sposobnost prilagodbe i širenja održive,  prema  zelenom  rastu  orijentirane,  kapitalno  raspodijeljene  ekonomije  koja  postaje  novi  standard  za  bolju  distribuciju resursa, postala je globalni prioritet. 
Sa  svijetom  koji  se  kreće  prema  novom  dobu održive i ekološki prihvatljive civilizacije, Hrvatska je, kao nova članica  Europske  Unije, spremna  napraviti  iskorak na globalnu pozornicu. Ne samo predstavljanjem svoje sjajne globalne reputacije  o  besprijekornoj  prirodi  koja  seže  od  povijesnih  regija  Panonije  do  jadranske  obale,  mora  i  preko  tisuću  otoka,  svojom  sportskom izvrsnošću, izuzetnim izumiteljima  i  znanstvenicima,  bezvremenskom  povijesnom  i  kulturnom  baštinom,  karakterističnim živahnim spojem raznolikosti i  putnicima koji o njoj sanjaju te je iznova  posjećuju, nego svojim inicijativama, težnjama i projektima globalnih standarda koji  pridonose univerzalnoj viziji. 
  Projekt  Croatia  Borealis,  znanstvena  i  kulturno-istraživačka ekspedicija pokrenula je 2016. godine udruge Kulturni Susreti  u suradnji sa Sveučilištem u Zagrebu, uz potporu predsjednika Republike Hrvatske Kolinda Grabar-Kitarović.

 

CILJEVI PROJEKTA SU

- Provesti specifične znanstveno istraživačke i stvaralačke projekte u sklopu multikulturalne i multidisciplinarne platforme 

- Potaknuti razgovor s raznim sudionicima tokom ekspedicije o globalnim i lokalnim problemima te mogućim rješenjima za klimatske, okolišne i druge promjene koje se događaju u svijetu 

- Podizati svijest i graditi doseg o globalnim i lokalnim okolišnim, klimatskim i drugim problemima te mogućim rješenjima kroz dokumentarnu seriju i izložbe o projektu

VIZIJE PROJEKTA SU

- Kontinuirano doprinositi pronalasku odgovora i rješenja na globalne i lokalne probleme promicanjem znanja, znanstvenih otkrića, kulture i umjetnosti 

 

O PROJEKTU

Ekspedicija  će  krenuti  iz  Vancouvera  (Kanada)  sjeverno Pacifikom uz zapadnu obalu sjevernoameričkoga  kontinenta,  proći  Beringovim  tjesnacem te oploviti  Aljasku. Slijedi prolaz arktičkim prostorima Sjeverozapadnoga prolaza, kojim je odnedavno ljeti, zbog globalnoga  zatopljenja ostvariva plovidba do Atlantika. Ekspedicija  će  ploviti  uz  obalu  Yukona  i  Sjeverozapadnog (Northwest) teritorija, Nunavuta  i  Quebeca,  zatim  Newfoundlanda i Labradora do Greenlanda gdje će završiti arktički  dio  ekspedicije.  Prvi  dio  putovanja  započet  će  u  lipnju  2017.a  završit  će  sto  dana  nakon  isplovljavanja.  Drugi  dio putovanja započet će na Islandu u lipnju 2018. i nastavit će put do Velike Britanije i zemalja Skandinavije sve  do St. Peterburga,a zatim južno ruskim rijekama i kanalima,  preko  Moskve  do  Crnoga  mora,  pa  kroz  Mramorno,  Egejsko  i  Jonsko  more  do  Jadranskog  mora  i  Splita  kao  konačne destinacije. 

Proučavanje nekih od najdelikatnijih te još nedovoljno istraženih područja na svijetu pruža mogućnost prikupljanja i obrade relevantnih znanstvenih podataka. Ova  ruta je također neiscrpan izvor inspiracije za brojne umjetnike iz raznih područja djelovanja.
                                      
U  svrhu  ekspedicije  bit  će  kupljen  trideset do četrdeset metara dug brod. Brod,  koji je ujedno i glavna platforma projekta,  bit će unaprijeđen obnovljivim i održivim  tehnologijama  te  opremljen  adekvatnim  laboratorijima i opremom za prikupljanje,  obradu  i  skladištenje  uzoraka  i  podataka  tijekom  ekspedicije.  Kandidati  iz  raznih  područja  prirodnih  i  društvenih  znanosti  poput  ekologije,  morske  biologije,  oceanogra je,  geograje,  geologije,  meteorologije,  astronomije,  antropologije,  sociologije,  ekonomije, prava te umjetnosti biti će pozvani  na  prijavu  za  rezidencije  kroz  poziv  i  kriterije koje će utvrditi akademski tim projekta. Projekt je u fazi dobivanja povratnih  informacija  i  komunikaciji  s  internacionalnim sveučilištima i institucijama te njihovim  kandidatima  o  specifičnim  temama  i  područjima njihovog istraživanja i djelovanja.
  Tijekom  ekspedicije projekt će se kontinuirano  interno  i  eksterno  usklađivati  u  interakciji  sa  sudionicima.  Značajan  naglasak  bit  će  na  razmjeni  kulture  i  znanja  s autohtonim zajednicama na ruti. Učenje  o njihovim  kulturama, iskustvima u odnosu  prema  okolišu  te  održivom  življenju  biti  će  od  neprocjenjive  vrijednosti.  Komunicirat  će  se  s  lokalnim  zajednicama,  učiti  i  raditi  zajedno  s  njihovima  znanstvenim,  kulturnim  i  vladinim  udrugama  u  potrazi  za  odgovorima  na  goruća  lokalna  i  globalna  pitanja.  Do  sada  smo  ostvarili  kontakt  i  zaprimili  pozitivno  pismo  namjere  od  kanadskih,  američkih  i  islandskih  sveučilišta  te  institucija.  Proces  komunikacije se nastavlja širiti i na ostale zemlje.

NAKON EKSPEDICIJE

Od znanstvenika i umjetnika će se očekivati  da  nastave  sa  svojim  istraživanjem  i  radom  po  završetku  svojih  rezidencija  na  brodu te povratku u svoje matične zemlje  i  institucije.  Sva  znanstvena  istraživanja  i  otkrića  tijekom  ekspedicije  Croatia  Borealis  bit  će  objavljena.  Zajedno  sa  znanstvenicima  i  njihovim  istraživanjima  umjetnici u rezidencijama tijekom ekspedicije  radit  će  na  kreacijama  iz  područja  fotografije, slikarstva, glazbe, književnosti,  eksperimentalnih i izvedbenih umjetnosti, usmjerenimaka  finalnom cilju, izložbi  za regionalnu i globalnu publiku u sklopu  koje će, na  fizičkim i virtualnim platformama, izložiti transformaciju svojih umijeća i  nadahnuća područjima kojima će ploviti i  temama kojima će se baviti.
  Dokumentarna  serija  bit  će  možda  najdalekosežniji  proizvod  ovog  projekta. Realizirat će je profesionalna  filmska  ekipa  koja  će  biti  stacionirana  na  brodu  ekspedicije,  opremljena  vrhunskom  snimateljskom  tehnologijom,  uz  odobrenje  jednog  od  najutjecajnijeg  kuratora  dokumentarnih   filmova  i  serija  u  regiji  i  šire, Đele Hadžiselimovića. 

U konačnici, potaknut će gledatelje  da  postanu  probuđeni  građani  ovoga svijeta, da razmisle o svom odnosu  prema  okolišu  i  posljedicama  istog,  inspirirati  ih  da  djeluju,  žive  svjesno  te  bolje usklade sebe i svoj život s univerzalnim  vrijednostima  koje  ovaj  projekt  ima za cilj promovirati.

Nakon projekta, naša namjera je donirati  ekspedicijski  brod  jednom  od  hrvatskih oceanografskih instituta gdje će  nastaviti služiti za daljnja znanstvena istraživanja i druge potrebne svrhe. 

 

UDRUGA KULTURNI SUSRETI

Osnovana 2004. godine pod imenom Kulturni Spektar, od 2015. godine djeluje pod sadašnjim imenom, udruga se bavi promocijom kulture i umjetnosti, od književnosti, likovnih i audiovizualnih umjetnosti do gastronomije i enologije.

Kao što joj i ime govori, cilj joj je promicati susrete hrvatske sa svjetskom kulturom i umjetnošću kroz mnoge inicijative, projekte, izložbe i druženja. Također, stipendira mlade nade hrvatske umjetnosti te aktivno sudjeluje u humanitarnom radu u Hrvatskoj i izvan nje. Možemo izdvojiti donaciju naših članova zakladama za pomoć izbjeglicama u europskoj migrantskoj krizi 2015. godine te prikupljanje sredstava za pomoć nakon tragedije u Fukushimi 2011. godine koja su kasnije predana japanskom veleposlanstvu u Hrvatskoj.

Udruga ima preko 500 članova, među kojima su nobelovci i oskarovci te i mnogi drugi hrvatski znanstvenici, umjetnici i intelektualci. Predsjednik udruge je Draško Romac, a jedan od značajnijih Draškovih projekata dosad bilo je putovanje tradicionalnim hrvatskim brodom, sedam i pol metara dugim leutom, europskim morima, rijekama i kanalima između 2010. i 2012. godine.
story_txt: 73 is a film collective of artists from all corners of Europe, intent on contributing to further the arts, film and natural world. The Croatia Borealis is a science and cultural research expedition, initiated in 2016 by the Cultural Encounters Association. This project is a collaboration with the University of Zagreb, and has received a letter of support from Croatian President Kolinda Grabar-Kitarović (see project images)We need your help to document and create films from this expedition, to share with all of you, to the benefit of all of us and our planet.This project, a modern naval expedition is an exploration of consciousness and ecological awareness, striving to the profound redefinition of the human civilization values that we all stand, work and live upon. We're a 21st century crew of innovation and inspiration; explorers, scientists and artists. With science, whose role is to provide firm facts on which the global policies will be based upon, art is the culmination of all the awareness, research and pursuits distilled into the symbolic embodiments, beyond-logic communication and higher dimensional creations set to engender the emotions in those who perceive it.This project is the embodiment of the new civilizational momentum and its consonants: science and culture, which have to unite, attune in collaborative efforts to address this issue and seek the better path along with this right course of history towards the reinvention our economy. Ability to adapt and procreate the sustainable, green-growth oriented, equity based economic order, which is becoming the new standard for better redistribution of resources, is becoming both short and long term global priority. THE PROJECT GOALS ARE- To conduct scientific research and artistic projects within a multicultural and multidisciplinary platform- To engage diverse stakeholders in conversation about global and local problems and possible solutions to climate, environmental and other changes happening in the world- To raise awareness about the global and local climate, environmental and other problems and their possible solutions through the documentaries and exhibitions about the project THE PROJECT VISION- Continuously contribute to finding the answers and solutions to global and local problems by promoting knowledge, scientific discoveries, culture and art THE EXPEDITIONThe expedition will sail out of Vancouver Island, Canada and follow the Pacific coast north, pass through the Bering Pass and sail around Alaska towards the Northwest Passage. Due to climate change and global heating the passage is opened for sailing, and Atlantic can be reached during the summertime. We will sail through the Northwest territory, Yukon, Nunavut and Quebec, followed by Newfoundland, Labrador and Greenland. The journey is planned to start on June 1, 2017 and will be completed approximately within one hundred days. The second part of the journey will start from Iceland in June, 2018 and go along the coast of the UK, through Scandinavia to St. Petersburg, down the Volga River through Moscow and continuing as far as the Black Sea reaching the waters of the Mediterranean Sea and the Adriatic, finally completing the journey in Split, Croatia. Due to financial and logistical requirements of the project and the internal decision making processes of our partners and sponsors it is possible that the start date of the expedition will be pushed for one year.Studying some of the most ecologically delicate, and yet not thoroughly explored, areas of the world offers a possibility to produce relevant scientific data. This route has also been an endless inspiration for many different artists in many different fields of art. Candidates from diverse fields of natural and social sciences such as ecology, oceanography, biology, geography, geology, meteorology, astronomy, anthropology, sociology, economics, law, and fine arts will be encouraged to apply for residencies through the process and merits set by our academic team.During the course of the expedition the project will reconcile within itself internally and externally in interaction with diverse stakeholders. A substantial emphasis in the project will be placed on the intercultural exchange and learning from the native communities en route. Establishing a dialogue and learning more about their diverse cultures, experiences in treating the environment and sustainable living will be an invaluable asset to this project. We will learn and work together with their scientific, cultural, government and non governmental establishments in search for solutions to pressing local and global issues. A ship, the platform for this expedition, will be acquired and improved with sustainable and renewable technologies, adequately equipped with several laboratories and research equipment needed for storing and processing of the gathered materials and data during the course of the journey.The project is currently in the phase of communication with international universities and institutions, seeking partnerships and gathering feedback about the specific research and work that will be undertaken during the course of this expedition. So far we have received a positive letter of engagement from Canadian and Icelandic universities. The communication process is continuous and will further include more countries and institutions in the project as the time goes by. Our intention is to seek support form the EU and other countries on the expedition route, while including their scientific and artistic communities as well as those from the countries beyond the expedition route. AFTER THE EXPEDITIONThe scientists and artists in residencies will continue their work in their home countries and institutions after their residencies. All scientific research and discoveries made during the project will be eventually published and made available to the public. Along with the scientists and their research, resident artists on board will work on fine-art creations, ranging from photography, paintings, music, literature to experimental or performing arts under a time-lined schedule eventually designated to a finale-exposé, an exhibition potent for regional and global audiences, from physical to virtual platforms, transducing ingenuity of inspirations from the areas that the expedition will explore.The film series will be perhaps the most far-reaching end product of this project. Produced by a professional film crew on board, equipped with top tier visual technology and with the approval of one of the most influential documentary selectors in Croatia, Mr. Đelo Hadžiselimović. Detailed scenery of the expedition, cultural, geographical, and ecological diversities will portrait the current state of the expedition route. Entertaining the lively atmosphere of the crew’s journey will give the films a narrative of an organic story about how the team grows together as the journey goes by. The emotions of the filmed participants, their thoughts, work and reactions will be inscripted and then moulded into a film series which will converge all of the above elements into key proactive statements which will provide its viewers with a valuable asset to take back home. Ultimately inspiring and encouraging the audience to become the awaken citizens of the world, appealing to rethink their current interaction with the environment and its consequences, inspiring to act and live consciously and better aligning their life with the universal values that this project promotes.This is where you come in; the international community. We need at least 50 000 USD to buy everything from drones to cameras with high-quality lenses and protective gear for the equipment. WITHOUT THIS THE PROJECT WON'T BE DOCUMENTED.HELP US GET THE WORD OUT AND MAKE SOME NOISE ABOUT THIS EXPEDITION AND OUR HOPE TO FILM IT.  - share this campaign wherever you can -ABOUT USThe Cultural Encounters Association was founded in 2004 in Zagreb, Croatia under the name Cultural Spectrum, and from 2015 has its present name. Currently it has over 500 members in record. Some of them are the Nobel laureates and Oscar winners, while others are Croatian scientists, artists and intellectuals.As its name states, the association also promotes international encounters between Croatia and the world culture through many initiatives, projects, exhibitions and various social events. The association is involved in presenting and promoting the work from many different areas of culture and arts, ranging from literature and fine arts to gastronomy and enology. In addition to awarding scholarships to young talented Croatian artists, the association also actively participates in charity work, both in Croatia and internationally. Among other projects, our members fundraised for the Fukushima disaster in 2011 in which case the sum was later donated to the Japan embassy in Croatia.Draško Romac, the president of the association, has a history of adventures of his own. Amidst traveling through the North American, European and Middle East roadways, the Leut project should be mentioned, as it involved a 7,5 meters long, 19th century Croatian fishing boat, which Draško refurbished and sailed through the European seas, rivers and channels between 2010 and 2012.73collective is a film production company working with clients in everything from arts and music, to fashion and technology. Founded in 2011, we’re based in Copenhagen, New York and Zagreb - where we're always developing our own artistic practice with personal projects, focusing on fiction and documentary filmmaking. The last five years we have made about 20 short films and documentaries, across four continents (Europe, North America, Africa and Asia), 30 music videos, live sessions, live events, commercial content, in addition to projects in other formats; museum and gallery exhibitions, composing music, releasing photo books and working with cinematic Virtual Reality experiences. We've screened several music videos at CPH PIX, been selected as residents of CPH DOX 2015' VR Workshop and made short films and documentaries nominated at festivals ranging from Message to Man in St. Petersburg to Doclisboa in Portugal, with "Shadow Fighters" (dir. Josefine Gervang Heimburger) winning 'Best East African Documentary' at Zanzibar International Film Festival 2015. Every contribution is welcome and perks range from a heartly thank you to joining the expedition ship! NA HRVATSKOM (in Croatian):Ovaj  projekt,  moderna  pomorska  ekspedicija,  reinvencija  je  davnih  aspiracija  s  ciljem  istraživanja  ekološke  osviještenosti  i  ljudske  svijesti,  s  težnjom  ka  temeljnoj  redefiniciji  civilizacijskih  vrijednosti  koje  zastupamo,  na  njima  radimo  i  živimo.  Modernu  posadu  21.  stoljeća  čini  vojska  inovacije  i  inspiracije, istraživači, znanstvenici i umjetnici.U vrijeme kada lokalne klimatske promjene  i zagađenje okoliša postaju evidentni dokazi  globalnog stanja, ovaj projekt ulazi upravo u  tu  stvarnost  potičući  znanstvena  istraživanja  i  otkrića,  odnosno  sakupljajući  podatke  nužnih  za  donošenje  dugoročnih  globalnih  regulativa,  koje  su  prijeko  potrebne.  Kako  bi  s kraja ove ere i ruba na kojem se trenutno nalazimo, kojeg znanstvenici nazivaju šestom krizom izumiranja krenuli naprijed prema četvrtoj  industrijskoj revoluciji vraćanje te ponovno uspostavljanje ravnoteže između ljudskog egzistencijalnog traga i okoliša, biosfere i klimatskih  promjena, suštinski je imperativ našega doba.Uz  znanost,  koja  je  tu  da  nam  osigura  čvrste činjenice na kojima će se zasnivati  globalni procesi odlučivanja, umjetnost  je kulminacija ljudske svijesti, istraživanja i stremljenja, pretočena u simbolička  utjelovljenja,  ne  uvijek  nužno  logične  oblike  komunikacije  te  više  dimenzionalne  kreacije  koje  imaju  sposobnost  izazivati emocije.Ovaj  projekt  utjelovljenje  je  novog  civilizacijskog  trenutka  i  njegovih  paradigmi  znanosti,  kulture  i  umjetnosti,  koje je potrebno ujediniti te zajedničkim  naporima  uskladiti  kako  bi  se  riješili problemi i pronašao bolji put prema  reinvenciji našeg  sustava  vrijednosti. Sposobnost prilagodbe i širenja održive,  prema  zelenom  rastu  orijentirane,  kapitalno  raspodijeljene  ekonomije  koja  postaje  novi  standard  za  bolju  distribuciju resursa, postala je globalni prioritet. Sa  svijetom  koji  se  kreće  prema  novom  dobu održive i ekološki prihvatljive civilizacije, Hrvatska je, kao nova članica  Europske  Unije, spremna  napraviti  iskorak na globalnu pozornicu. Ne samo predstavljanjem svoje sjajne globalne reputacije  o  besprijekornoj  prirodi  koja  seže  od  povijesnih  regija  Panonije  do  jadranske  obale,  mora  i  preko  tisuću  otoka,  svojom  sportskom izvrsnošću, izuzetnim izumiteljima  i  znanstvenicima,  bezvremenskom  povijesnom  i  kulturnom  baštinom,  karakterističnim živahnim spojem raznolikosti i  putnicima koji o njoj sanjaju te je iznova  posjećuju, nego svojim inicijativama, težnjama i projektima globalnih standarda koji  pridonose univerzalnoj viziji.   Projekt  Croatia  Borealis,  znanstvena  i  kulturno-istraživačka ekspedicija pokrenula je 2016. godine udruge Kulturni Susreti  u suradnji sa Sveučilištem u Zagrebu, uz potporu predsjednika Republike Hrvatske Kolinda Grabar-Kitarović. CILJEVI PROJEKTA SU- Provesti specifične znanstveno istraživačke i stvaralačke projekte u sklopu multikulturalne i multidisciplinarne platforme - Potaknuti razgovor s raznim sudionicima tokom ekspedicije o globalnim i lokalnim problemima te mogućim rješenjima za klimatske, okolišne i druge promjene koje se događaju u svijetu - Podizati svijest i graditi doseg o globalnim i lokalnim okolišnim, klimatskim i drugim problemima te mogućim rješenjima kroz dokumentarnu seriju i izložbe o projektuVIZIJE PROJEKTA SU- Kontinuirano doprinositi pronalasku odgovora i rješenja na globalne i lokalne probleme promicanjem znanja, znanstvenih otkrića, kulture i umjetnosti  O PROJEKTUEkspedicija  će  krenuti  iz  Vancouvera  (Kanada)  sjeverno Pacifikom uz zapadnu obalu sjevernoameričkoga  kontinenta,  proći  Beringovim  tjesnacem te oploviti  Aljasku. Slijedi prolaz arktičkim prostorima Sjeverozapadnoga prolaza, kojim je odnedavno ljeti, zbog globalnoga  zatopljenja ostvariva plovidba do Atlantika. Ekspedicija  će  ploviti  uz  obalu  Yukona  i  Sjeverozapadnog (Northwest) teritorija, Nunavuta  i  Quebeca,  zatim  Newfoundlanda i Labradora do Greenlanda gdje će završiti arktički  dio  ekspedicije.  Prvi  dio  putovanja  započet  će  u  lipnju  2017.a  završit  će  sto  dana  nakon  isplovljavanja.  Drugi  dio putovanja započet će na Islandu u lipnju 2018. i nastavit će put do Velike Britanije i zemalja Skandinavije sve  do St. Peterburga,a zatim južno ruskim rijekama i kanalima,  preko  Moskve  do  Crnoga  mora,  pa  kroz  Mramorno,  Egejsko  i  Jonsko  more  do  Jadranskog  mora  i  Splita  kao  konačne destinacije. Proučavanje nekih od najdelikatnijih te još nedovoljno istraženih područja na svijetu pruža mogućnost prikupljanja i obrade relevantnih znanstvenih podataka. Ova  ruta je također neiscrpan izvor inspiracije za brojne umjetnike iz raznih područja djelovanja.                                      U  svrhu  ekspedicije  bit  će  kupljen  trideset do četrdeset metara dug brod. Brod,  koji je ujedno i glavna platforma projekta,  bit će unaprijeđen obnovljivim i održivim  tehnologijama  te  opremljen  adekvatnim  laboratorijima i opremom za prikupljanje,  obradu  i  skladištenje  uzoraka  i  podataka  tijekom  ekspedicije.  Kandidati  iz  raznih  područja  prirodnih  i  društvenih  znanosti  poput  ekologije,  morske  biologije,  oceanogra je,  geograje,  geologije,  meteorologije,  astronomije,  antropologije,  sociologije,  ekonomije, prava te umjetnosti biti će pozvani  na  prijavu  za  rezidencije  kroz  poziv  i  kriterije koje će utvrditi akademski tim projekta. Projekt je u fazi dobivanja povratnih  informacija  i  komunikaciji  s  internacionalnim sveučilištima i institucijama te njihovim  kandidatima  o  specifičnim  temama  i  područjima njihovog istraživanja i djelovanja.  Tijekom  ekspedicije projekt će se kontinuirano  interno  i  eksterno  usklađivati  u  interakciji  sa  sudionicima.  Značajan  naglasak  bit  će  na  razmjeni  kulture  i  znanja  s autohtonim zajednicama na ruti. Učenje  o njihovim  kulturama, iskustvima u odnosu  prema  okolišu  te  održivom  življenju  biti  će  od  neprocjenjive  vrijednosti.  Komunicirat  će  se  s  lokalnim  zajednicama,  učiti  i  raditi  zajedno  s  njihovima  znanstvenim,  kulturnim  i  vladinim  udrugama  u  potrazi  za  odgovorima  na  goruća  lokalna  i  globalna  pitanja.  Do  sada  smo  ostvarili  kontakt  i  zaprimili  pozitivno  pismo  namjere  od  kanadskih,  američkih  i  islandskih  sveučilišta  te  institucija.  Proces  komunikacije se nastavlja širiti i na ostale zemlje.NAKON EKSPEDICIJEOd znanstvenika i umjetnika će se očekivati  da  nastave  sa  svojim  istraživanjem  i  radom  po  završetku  svojih  rezidencija  na  brodu te povratku u svoje matične zemlje  i  institucije.  Sva  znanstvena  istraživanja  i  otkrića  tijekom  ekspedicije  Croatia  Borealis  bit  će  objavljena.  Zajedno  sa  znanstvenicima  i  njihovim  istraživanjima  umjetnici u rezidencijama tijekom ekspedicije  radit  će  na  kreacijama  iz  područja  fotografije, slikarstva, glazbe, književnosti,  eksperimentalnih i izvedbenih umjetnosti, usmjerenimaka  finalnom cilju, izložbi  za regionalnu i globalnu publiku u sklopu  koje će, na  fizičkim i virtualnim platformama, izložiti transformaciju svojih umijeća i  nadahnuća područjima kojima će ploviti i  temama kojima će se baviti.  Dokumentarna  serija  bit  će  možda  najdalekosežniji  proizvod  ovog  projekta. Realizirat će je profesionalna  filmska  ekipa  koja  će  biti  stacionirana  na  brodu  ekspedicije,  opremljena  vrhunskom  snimateljskom  tehnologijom,  uz  odobrenje  jednog  od  najutjecajnijeg  kuratora  dokumentarnih   filmova  i  serija  u  regiji  i  šire, Đele Hadžiselimovića. U konačnici, potaknut će gledatelje  da  postanu  probuđeni  građani  ovoga svijeta, da razmisle o svom odnosu  prema  okolišu  i  posljedicama  istog,  inspirirati  ih  da  djeluju,  žive  svjesno  te  bolje usklade sebe i svoj život s univerzalnim  vrijednostima  koje  ovaj  projekt  ima za cilj promovirati.Nakon projekta, naša namjera je donirati  ekspedicijski  brod  jednom  od  hrvatskih oceanografskih instituta gdje će  nastaviti služiti za daljnja znanstvena istraživanja i druge potrebne svrhe.  UDRUGA KULTURNI SUSRETIOsnovana 2004. godine pod imenom Kulturni Spektar, od 2015. godine djeluje pod sadašnjim imenom, udruga se bavi promocijom kulture i umjetnosti, od književnosti, likovnih i audiovizualnih umjetnosti do gastronomije i enologije.Kao što joj i ime govori, cilj joj je promicati susrete hrvatske sa svjetskom kulturom i umjetnošću kroz mnoge inicijative, projekte, izložbe i druženja. Također, stipendira mlade nade hrvatske umjetnosti te aktivno sudjeluje u humanitarnom radu u Hrvatskoj i izvan nje. Možemo izdvojiti donaciju naših članova zakladama za pomoć izbjeglicama u europskoj migrantskoj krizi 2015. godine te prikupljanje sredstava za pomoć nakon tragedije u Fukushimi 2011. godine koja su kasnije predana japanskom veleposlanstvu u Hrvatskoj.Udruga ima preko 500 članova, među kojima su nobelovci i oskarovci te i mnogi drugi hrvatski znanstvenici, umjetnici i intelektualci. Predsjednik udruge je Draško Romac, a jedan od značajnijih Draškovih projekata dosad bilo je putovanje tradicionalnim hrvatskim brodom, sedam i pol metara dugim leutom, europskim morima, rijekama i kanalima između 2010. i 2012. godine.

story:
Short Summary

At the end of 2017, Bali declared a garbage emergency as the island reached crisis point after struggling to get on top of its rubbish management issues. Penelope Williams, executive chef and owner of Bali Asli, a cooking school and restaurant on the foothills of Mt Agung in East Bali, decided she had to do something. Working alongside the chiefs from the villages surrounding Bali Asli, she’s found a hands-on solution that she believes will inspire the government to take action.

What is Bali Asli?

Bali Asli, which means “authentic” or “genuine” Bali, is a restaurant with a cooking school located in East Bali near the foothills of Bali’s infamous volcano, Mt Agung.

Bali Asli came to life in June 2011, with the purpose of not only providing visitors with authentic Balinese cuisine so that they can taste the ‘real’ Bali, but also creating adventures that allow them to see, touch and experience the island’s culture in a way that provides an immersive experience that nourishes the body and the soul, and provides a greater understanding of the Balinese way of life. Penelope Williams, the owner of Bali Asli, found that authentic Balinese cuisine was almost impossible for visitors to the island to access. As a chef who had been living in the region for several years, she had begun to explore the vitality and intricacies of the cusinese and was deeply saddened that people would come to Bali, eat chicken sate with peanut sauce, nasi goreng and mie goreng and think that they had eaten Balinese food. Bali Asli is her way of sharing the soul of Balinese cuisine.

In keeping with her vision of providing a traditional experience, Penelope constructed Bali Asli to be at one with its environment. An eco-friendly establishment, the building and its underlying concepts use natural materials and traditional Balinese design and has no electrical appliances (everything is made using good old fashioned elbow grease), to ensure minimal impact on the environment.

Penelope would now like to take this eco-friendly ethos to the wider community, making social change and giving back to the Balinese community a greater extension of Bali Asli’s purpose.

Why Bali Asli Needs Your Help

As you walk up the dark stone staircase that marks the entrance to Bali Asli and pass through the carved timber doorway at the top, you will find yourself breathless, and not due to the stairs you have just climbed. The long earth-toned restaurant space opens out seamlessly into an expansive deck that overlooks lush green wrinkles of rice paddy fields, while Bali’s most sacred mountain, Mt Agung, rises like a mystical guardian in the distance.

But beneath the surface of this beauty and tranquility lies a darker underbelly. Bali, the paradise island, is now drowning in its own rubbish.
