Over her 10 years in Bali, Penelope has witnessed how a lack of rubbish management, education and infrastructure available to the Balinese people, and an increasing influx of tourists, has seen the rivers and oceans increasingly being inundated with waste. When it rains, all the rubbish that is disposed of without care is washed up out of the blocked rivers, drains and roadside gutters onto beaches, roads, footpaths, gardens, parks where children play and further into the ocean.

The current, “out of sight, out of mind” mantra isn’t working and Bali is in a state of crisis with the island having recently declared a garbage emergency.

The Facts

  • Up to 75% of Bali’s garbage is not collected by official services.
  • There are only five legal garbage dumps on the entire island. Because it is so far to transport waste, 50% of it is dumped.
  • Makeshift rubbish dumps are everywhere due to poor governance.
  • Every 24 hours, 15,000 cubic meters of trash is disposed of along Bali’s roadsides and at illegal dump sites, enough to completely fill six Olympic sized swimming pools every day.
  • Indonesia is the second biggest maritime plastic polluter in the world after China.

Really, this problem is the responsibility of the Indonesian government, just the same as other governments around the world have to take responsibility to educate the population and put in place the infrastructure to support education. But to make this a focus for authorities is a difficult task. There comes a point, when matters have to be taken into our hands as citizens of planet earth in order to inspire change and do the right thing. Just waiting on local government initiatives to take action isn’t the solution especially when things have become so dire.

Penelope  knows she must do something to help. Something that can help create tangible positive change to Bali’s massive rubbish problem. And she needs your help to do it.

Starting Locally

The rubbish problem in Bali is monumental and Penelope wants to start by first cleaning up her own backyard. The three villages (Gelumpang, Jeruk Manis and Tauka) that surround Bali Asli need support and education to manage their rubbish.

Currently there is no rubbish collection service provided by the government to collect rubbish from these villages. The people have created a designated area for dumping and then burning the rubbish, and worse - there are additional places where it gets thrown in the river. The schools in these villages comply with the government and try to teach the children about rubbish management and recycling, and most Sundays the school and the children’s family join to clean up the streets. However, like so many other cases, the community doesn’t yet understand that this has to become a way of life.

Proposed Solution

Bali Asli Rubbish Education Program
Penelope will launch the Bali Asli Rubbish Education Program, a sustainable program which focuses on strategies that are based around education, discussion and action. The initiative will work with village chiefs and their communities to get them involved by playing active roles in the scheme. Sturdy rubbish bins will be built in each village with separate sections for organic, non organic and plastic bottles. Cane rubbish baskets will be delivered to every home in the three villages surrounding Bali Asli (Gelumpang, Jeruk Manis and Tauka) and tricycles will be provided to pick up rubbish from these villages’ central bins, and taken to legal refuse centers.

Bali Asli Eco Refillery
Penelope aims to launch refill stations at local markets across Bali, starting with the local Amlapura market. The ‘refillery’ station will sell shampoo, shower gel, washing liquid and other household goods from bulk purchased containers using recycled refill bottles. The locals would come to these stations with their own bottles (or we will provide them with free bottles) and fill/refill them with whatever daily essentials they require. In doing so, there would be a reduction in the amount of plastic waste created by single portion shampoo and shower gel sachets and single-use plastic bottles. There will also be an incentive program put in place to encourage people to keep re-using their bottles. 

Every purchase will come with an educational pack around sustainable living and 50% of all profit from the refillery will go directly back into the education program to assist in ongoing education.

What your contribution will fund

Launch Rubbish Education Program
Cost:  73,900
The program will be launched across the three villages surrounding Bali Asli (Gelumpang, Jeruk Manis and Tauka and will include:

  • Hiring locals for regular rubbish collection for a period of one year.
  • Environmental educators for a period of one year.
  • Buying the rubbish bins and tricycles.
  • Creating educational packs.
  • Creating a refreshed website that includes the initiative and online resources.
  • Marketing collateral including a series of short films that help build awareness around the problem in order to drive change throughout Bali and beyond. 

Launch Eco Refillery
Cost: 13,900

The Refill Station will be launched in Amlapura market and if successful, will be pushed out in markets across Bali.

  • Initial setup costs for market, including stall rent for 1 year.
  • Staff salary for 1 year.
  • Bulk goods including soaps, shampoo, shower gel, dishwashing liquid, clothes washing liquid.
  • Reusable recycled bags (made from old sarongs and cloth) which will be given out to locals for free to assist them in moving towards a more sustainable future.   
  • Marketing collateral, to help spread the message.

What We Will Achieve

  • Over 3,000 locals living in the three villages surrounding Bali Asli are empowered to harness a more sustainable way of living.
  • Garbage is disposed of sustainably in the three villages surrounding Bali Asli.
  • Locals and tourists have a more profound appreciation for the land, where a cleaner environment and sustainable living becomes a priority, and a new sense of pride is given to locals.
  • The Rubbish Education Program is supported by the local Mayor within 12-months and receives financial support to continue the cost of refuse collection, educational resources are boosted and the initiative is widened to cater to the entire island. 
  • Additional refilleries are launched across Bali that encourage sustainability, create jobs and empower the Balinese people.
  • A greener, cleaner and healthier Bali for the inhabitants of the region and everyone that visits it.

Further Details For Perks
*Please note that all perks can be gifted. To choose a perk, look at the bar on the right. 
 

$10+ A credit of appreciation
Your financial backing is greatly appreciated. To acknowledge your contribution in helping us make this project a reality, your name will be displayed on our "Rubbish Warriors" wall of fame in Bali, Indonesia

$20+ 1 Video Recipe + PDF
We’ll send you a video recipe that features executive chef Penelope Williams creating one of her authentic Balinese dishes. We have three recipes to choose from, including Spiced Fish Fillet in a Banana Leaf Parcel or Fern Tips with Grated Coconut and Red Beans or Spiced Tofu Banana Leaf Parcel. Plus, you'll get all the perks above.

$50 + 2 Video Recipes + PDF'S
We’ll send you two video recipes that features executive chef Penelope Williams creating two of her authentic Balinese dishes. We have three recipes to choose from, including Spiced Fish Fillet in a Banana Leaf Parcel or Fern Tips with Grated Coconut and Red Beans or Spiced Tofu Banana Leaf Parcel. Plus, you'll get all the perks above.

$100+ 7 Video Recipes + PDF's
We’ll send you 7 video recipes that feature executive chef Penelope Williams creating her authentic Balinese dishes. These video recipes and PDF's are usually only available to Bali Asli guest so if you can't visit Bali Asli, they are the next best thing!

$200+ 1 hour Cooking Class Webinar
An ‘exclusive to backers’ one hour cooking class webinar with executive chef, Penelope Williams. In this webinar, streamed live from Bali, Indonesia, you’ll learn about one of Penelope’s favourite dishes and be taught how to create it. At the end of the session, you’ll also have the opportunity to ask Penelope anything. Plus, all the perks above.

$400+ Exclusive half day culinary adventure for two 
An exclusive half day culinary adventure, created especially for backers. Join executive chef Penelope Williams on her visit to Amlapura morning market to gather the produce for your cooking class. Sample produce and absorb real Balinese action in the hustle and bustle of the market. Return to Bali Asli and learn how to prepare traditional flower offerings, “canang” before cooking your lunch using traditional equipment and techniques.
*Does not include flights, accommodation or airport transfers. However, Bali Asli would be happy to help you arrange this for you once you are Bali.

$1,400+ Exclusive full day culinary adventure for two, including 1 night’s accommodation
An exclusive full day culinary adventure for two that includes a quick trip to one of the villages where the Education Program has been implemented. This itinerary has been created especially for backers. Join executive chef Penelope Williams in Bali on a full day trekking adventure.You’ll be taken up into the village of Pangi, where you will have the opportunity to peek into the daily life of the Balinese. As well as enjoying stunning views over rice fields, ocean and volcanoes you will see Balinese palm wine being made. From here, you will be taken on a quick trip through Tauke, one of the villages where the Education Program has been implemented, before wandering through the rice fields back to Bali Asli for a traditional cooking class. After you’ve had your fill and a bit of rest and relaxation, finish your day with a bike ride through the villages and rice paddies surrounding Bali Asli back to your accommodation.
*Does not include flights or airport transfers. However, Bali Asli would be happy to help you arrange your transfers once you arrive in Bali.

$3,600+ Exclusive two day culinary adventure and rubbish education program tour for two, including 2 nights accommodation
See first hand the fruits of your support with a private tour led by Penelope Williams that takes you through the villages where the rubbish education program has been implemented. This is followed by a cooking class and lunch at Bali Asli. In the evening, embark on an epic adventure to the street stalls and night markets in Amlapura town. Here, you can eat dinner with the locals and experience authentic Bali, before being taken back to your accommodation for the evening. The next day, venture into Bali’s spiritual heart on a 2.5 hours hike to the top of Lempuyang temple. This sacred journey will wind through misty ancient pandan forests, vanilla vines, native orchids, along a combination of grassy paths lined with lemongrass and steep rocky tracks. Once you reach the summit you are rewarded with breathtaking views overlooking the Karangasem valley to the ocean and across to mighty Mount Agung, Bali’s famous volcano. After a morning coffee and some jajan cakes, you will be taken into the temple where the priest will bless you with holy water collected from the insides of the bamboo growing near the temple. Your descent will be via the 1700 steps, passing many other sacred temples and places of spiritual importance. You will then be taken back to Bali Asli for a well earned megibung lunch, served in the style of the Royal family of Karangasem. In the afternoon, you’ll be able to enjoy some time in a Balinese beauty salon; learn about the healing herbs of Bali, make traditional skin and beauty products from ingredients such as coffee, chocolate, honey, coconut, and exotic flowers, and test them out on yourself or your friend.
*Does not include flights or airport transfers. However, Bali Asli would be happy to help you arrange your transfers once you arrive in Bali.
story_txt:
Short SummaryAt the end of 2017, Bali declared a garbage emergency as the island reached crisis point after struggling to get on top of its rubbish management issues. Penelope Williams, executive chef and owner of Bali Asli, a cooking school and restaurant on the foothills of Mt Agung in East Bali, decided she had to do something. Working alongside the chiefs from the villages surrounding Bali Asli, she’s found a hands-on solution that she believes will inspire the government to take action.What is Bali Asli?Bali Asli, which means “authentic” or “genuine” Bali, is a restaurant with a cooking school located in East Bali near the foothills of Bali’s infamous volcano, Mt Agung.Bali Asli came to life in June 2011, with the purpose of not only providing visitors with authentic Balinese cuisine so that they can taste the ‘real’ Bali, but also creating adventures that allow them to see, touch and experience the island’s culture in a way that provides an immersive experience that nourishes the body and the soul, and provides a greater understanding of the Balinese way of life. Penelope Williams, the owner of Bali Asli, found that authentic Balinese cuisine was almost impossible for visitors to the island to access. As a chef who had been living in the region for several years, she had begun to explore the vitality and intricacies of the cusinese and was deeply saddened that people would come to Bali, eat chicken sate with peanut sauce, nasi goreng and mie goreng and think that they had eaten Balinese food. Bali Asli is her way of sharing the soul of Balinese cuisine.In keeping with her vision of providing a traditional experience, Penelope constructed Bali Asli to be at one with its environment. An eco-friendly establishment, the building and its underlying concepts use natural materials and traditional Balinese design and has no electrical appliances (everything is made using good old fashioned elbow grease), to ensure minimal impact on the environment.Penelope would now like to take this eco-friendly ethos to the wider community, making social change and giving back to the Balinese community a greater extension of Bali Asli’s purpose.Why Bali Asli Needs Your HelpAs you walk up the dark stone staircase that marks the entrance to Bali Asli and pass through the carved timber doorway at the top, you will find yourself breathless, and not due to the stairs you have just climbed. The long earth-toned restaurant space opens out seamlessly into an expansive deck that overlooks lush green wrinkles of rice paddy fields, while Bali’s most sacred mountain, Mt Agung, rises like a mystical guardian in the distance.But beneath the surface of this beauty and tranquility lies a darker underbelly. Bali, the paradise island, is now drowning in its own rubbish. Over her 10 years in Bali, Penelope has witnessed how a lack of rubbish management, education and infrastructure available to the Balinese people, and an increasing influx of tourists, has seen the rivers and oceans increasingly being inundated with waste. When it rains, all the rubbish that is disposed of without care is washed up out of the blocked rivers, drains and roadside gutters onto beaches, roads, footpaths, gardens, parks where children play and further into the ocean.The current, “out of sight, out of mind” mantra isn’t working and Bali is in a state of crisis with the island having recently declared a garbage emergency.The Facts
Up to 75% of Bali’s garbage is not collected by official services.
There are only five legal garbage dumps on the entire island. Because it is so far to transport waste, 50% of it is dumped.
Makeshift rubbish dumps are everywhere due to poor governance.
Every 24 hours, 15,000 cubic meters of trash is disposed of along Bali’s roadsides and at illegal dump sites, enough to completely fill six Olympic sized swimming pools every day.
Indonesia is the second biggest maritime plastic polluter in the world after China.
Really, this problem is the responsibility of the Indonesian government, just the same as other governments around the world have to take responsibility to educate the population and put in place the infrastructure to support education. But to make this a focus for authorities is a difficult task. There comes a point, when matters have to be taken into our hands as citizens of planet earth in order to inspire change and do the right thing. Just waiting on local government initiatives to take action isn’t the solution especially when things have become so dire.Penelope  knows she must do something to help. Something that can help create tangible positive change to Bali’s massive rubbish problem. And she needs your help to do it.Starting LocallyThe rubbish problem in Bali is monumental and Penelope wants to start by first cleaning up her own backyard. The three villages (Gelumpang, Jeruk Manis and Tauka) that surround Bali Asli need support and education to manage their rubbish.Currently there is no rubbish collection service provided by the government to collect rubbish from these villages. The people have created a designated area for dumping and then burning the rubbish, and worse - there are additional places where it gets thrown in the river. The schools in these villages comply with the government and try to teach the children about rubbish management and recycling, and most Sundays the school and the children’s family join to clean up the streets. However, like so many other cases, the community doesn’t yet understand that this has to become a way of life.Proposed SolutionBali Asli Rubbish Education ProgramPenelope will launch the Bali Asli Rubbish Education Program, a sustainable program which focuses on strategies that are based around education, discussion and action. The initiative will work with village chiefs and their communities to get them involved by playing active roles in the scheme. Sturdy rubbish bins will be built in each village with separate sections for organic, non organic and plastic bottles. Cane rubbish baskets will be delivered to every home in the three villages surrounding Bali Asli (Gelumpang, Jeruk Manis and Tauka) and tricycles will be provided to pick up rubbish from these villages’ central bins, and taken to legal refuse centers.
Bali Asli Eco RefilleryPenelope aims to launch refill stations at local markets across Bali, starting with the local Amlapura market. The ‘refillery’ station will sell shampoo, shower gel, washing liquid and other household goods from bulk purchased containers using recycled refill bottles. The locals would come to these stations with their own bottles (or we will provide them with free bottles) and fill/refill them with whatever daily essentials they require. In doing so, there would be a reduction in the amount of plastic waste created by single portion shampoo and shower gel sachets and single-use plastic bottles. There will also be an incentive program put in place to encourage people to keep re-using their bottles. Every purchase will come with an educational pack around sustainable living and 50% of all profit from the refillery will go directly back into the education program to assist in ongoing education.What your contribution will fundLaunch Rubbish Education ProgramCost:  73,900The program will be launched across the three villages surrounding Bali Asli (Gelumpang, Jeruk Manis and Tauka and will include:
Hiring locals for regular rubbish collection for a period of one year.
Environmental educators for a period of one year.
Buying the rubbish bins and tricycles.
Creating educational packs.
Creating a refreshed website that includes the initiative and online resources.
Marketing collateral including a series of short films that help build awareness around the problem in order to drive change throughout Bali and beyond. 
Launch Eco RefilleryCost: 13,900The Refill Station will be launched in Amlapura market and if successful, will be pushed out in markets across Bali.
Initial setup costs for market, including stall rent for 1 year.
Staff salary for 1 year.
Bulk goods including soaps, shampoo, shower gel, dishwashing liquid, clothes washing liquid.
Reusable recycled bags (made from old sarongs and cloth) which will be given out to locals for free to assist them in moving towards a more sustainable future.   
Marketing collateral, to help spread the message.
What We Will Achieve
Over 3,000 locals living in the three villages surrounding Bali Asli are empowered to harness a more sustainable way of living.
Garbage is disposed of sustainably in the three villages surrounding Bali Asli.
Locals and tourists have a more profound appreciation for the land, where a cleaner environment and sustainable living becomes a priority, and a new sense of pride is given to locals.
The Rubbish Education Program is supported by the local Mayor within 12-months and receives financial support to continue the cost of refuse collection, educational resources are boosted and the initiative is widened to cater to the entire island. 
Additional refilleries are launched across Bali that encourage sustainability, create jobs and empower the Balinese people.
A greener, cleaner and healthier Bali for the inhabitants of the region and everyone that visits it.
Further Details For Perks*Please note that all perks can be gifted. To choose a perk, look at the bar on the right.  $10+ A credit of appreciationYour financial backing is greatly appreciated. To acknowledge your contribution in helping us make this project a reality, your name will be displayed on our "Rubbish Warriors" wall of fame in Bali, Indonesia$20+ 1 Video Recipe + PDFWe’ll send you a video recipe that features executive chef Penelope Williams creating one of her authentic Balinese dishes. We have three recipes to choose from, including Spiced Fish Fillet in a Banana Leaf Parcel or Fern Tips with Grated Coconut and Red Beans or Spiced Tofu Banana Leaf Parcel. Plus, you'll get all the perks above.$50 + 2 Video Recipes + PDF'SWe’ll send you two video recipes that features executive chef Penelope Williams creating two of her authentic Balinese dishes. We have three recipes to choose from, including Spiced Fish Fillet in a Banana Leaf Parcel or Fern Tips with Grated Coconut and Red Beans or Spiced Tofu Banana Leaf Parcel. Plus, you'll get all the perks above.$100+ 7 Video Recipes + PDF'sWe’ll send you 7 video recipes that feature executive chef Penelope Williams creating her authentic Balinese dishes. These video recipes and PDF's are usually only available to Bali Asli guest so if you can't visit Bali Asli, they are the next best thing!$200+ 1 hour Cooking Class WebinarAn ‘exclusive to backers’ one hour cooking class webinar with executive chef, Penelope Williams. In this webinar, streamed live from Bali, Indonesia, you’ll learn about one of Penelope’s favourite dishes and be taught how to create it. At the end of the session, you’ll also have the opportunity to ask Penelope anything. Plus, all the perks above.$400+ Exclusive half day culinary adventure for two An exclusive half day culinary adventure, created especially for backers. Join executive chef Penelope Williams on her visit to Amlapura morning market to gather the produce for your cooking class. Sample produce and absorb real Balinese action in the hustle and bustle of the market. Return to Bali Asli and learn how to prepare traditional flower offerings, “canang” before cooking your lunch using traditional equipment and techniques.*Does not include flights, accommodation or airport transfers. However, Bali Asli would be happy to help you arrange this for you once you are Bali.$1,400+ Exclusive full day culinary adventure for two, including 1 night’s accommodationAn exclusive full day culinary adventure for two that includes a quick trip to one of the villages where the Education Program has been implemented. This itinerary has been created especially for backers. Join executive chef Penelope Williams in Bali on a full day trekking adventure.You’ll be taken up into the village of Pangi, where you will have the opportunity to peek into the daily life of the Balinese. As well as enjoying stunning views over rice fields, ocean and volcanoes you will see Balinese palm wine being made. From here, you will be taken on a quick trip through Tauke, one of the villages where the Education Program has been implemented, before wandering through the rice fields back to Bali Asli for a traditional cooking class. After you’ve had your fill and a bit of rest and relaxation, finish your day with a bike ride through the villages and rice paddies surrounding Bali Asli back to your accommodation.*Does not include flights or airport transfers. However, Bali Asli would be happy to help you arrange your transfers once you arrive in Bali.$3,600+ Exclusive two day culinary adventure and rubbish education program tour for two, including 2 nights accommodationSee first hand the fruits of your support with a private tour led by Penelope Williams that takes you through the villages where the rubbish education program has been implemented. This is followed by a cooking class and lunch at Bali Asli. In the evening, embark on an epic adventure to the street stalls and night markets in Amlapura town. Here, you can eat dinner with the locals and experience authentic Bali, before being taken back to your accommodation for the evening. The next day, venture into Bali’s spiritual heart on a 2.5 hours hike to the top of Lempuyang temple. This sacred journey will wind through misty ancient pandan forests, vanilla vines, native orchids, along a combination of grassy paths lined with lemongrass and steep rocky tracks. Once you reach the summit you are rewarded with breathtaking views overlooking the Karangasem valley to the ocean and across to mighty Mount Agung, Bali’s famous volcano. After a morning coffee and some jajan cakes, you will be taken into the temple where the priest will bless you with holy water collected from the insides of the bamboo growing near the temple. Your descent will be via the 1700 steps, passing many other sacred temples and places of spiritual importance. You will then be taken back to Bali Asli for a well earned megibung lunch, served in the style of the Royal family of Karangasem. In the afternoon, you’ll be able to enjoy some time in a Balinese beauty salon; learn about the healing herbs of Bali, make traditional skin and beauty products from ingredients such as coffee, chocolate, honey, coconut, and exotic flowers, and test them out on yourself or your friend.*Does not include flights or airport transfers. However, Bali Asli would be happy to help you arrange your transfers once you arrive in Bali.

story:
Saves Water, Saves Money, Saves Your Landscaping

The Water Recycling System, know as WRESY™, is a unique application designed to give residential and commercial property owners the ability to recapture water from irrigation and rain runoff that can be recycled through their existing sprinkler systems.

It is estimated that approximately 50% of all water used for domestic household irrigation is currently going down the drain... due primarily to waste water runoff & outdated irrigation practices. The WRESY™ System helps recapture and reuse that water while saving natural resources and reducing water bills.

Want to See How The WRESY™ System Works?

Watch this short video on how a typical residential installation works:


How Much Water Do We Waste Outdoors? 

http://www.epa.gov/WaterSense/pubs/outdoor.html – According to the EPA “The average American family uses 320 gallons of water per day, about 30 percent of which is devoted to outdoor uses.” (“In dry climates such as the Southwest, a household’s outdoor water use can be as high as 60 percent.“)…In addition, some experts estimate that as much as 50 percent of water used for irrigation is wasted due to evaporation, wind, or runoff caused by inefficient irrigation methods and systems.” - See more at: http://www.wresy.com/an-average-california-home...

Yard sprinklers generate runoff during every watering process causing valuable water to be wasted. A typical residential irrigation system can produce upwards of 250 to 500 gallons of runoff per cycle, depending on the topography & soil composition of the property... Now... while reducing your irrigation cycle can help reduce water usage, it can also result in insufficient watering and damage to your landscaping.

WRESY™ collects sprinkler and rain runoff in its patented holding tanks concealed underground. When the WRESY tanks are full, the system is armed and ready to recycle that water back thru your existing sprinkler system keeping your landscaping healthy and lush. Wasted water is now a thing of the past with WRESY™… We’re working together, for a better & wetter tomorrow! 

How Can You Help...

We currently have 3 Pilot Systems installed in San Diego County, but now we need your help to continue... WRESY™ needs technical upgrades to make it a bigger, smarter, stronger water recycling machine!

We require $20,000 in order to improve WRESY™ in the following areas:


What You Get for Supporting Us...

In return for your support, WRESY™ will send you a personalized Thank You Letter for helping Us create a more water efficient future for our homes and businesses... and for those folks that contribute $20 or more, you will also receive an official   "Drought Dodger" Certificate that commemorates your dedication to saving water
during this historic California Drought.   Please be sure to select one of the listed perks to ensure you receive your support gifts.

For those of you who can contribute more we are offering exclusive WRESY™ merchandise, including: 

  • A custom designed t-shirt 
  • A custom embroidered "trucker-style" MESH-Fit hat
  • An Irrigation Efficiency Package - includes 25 Rain Bird® HE-VAN Series
    High Efficiency Variable Arc Nozzles, a Water Saving Hose Nozzle with "Volume Control Dial" and the Poly-Gator 5-in-One Irrigation Installation Tool

Please read the individual perk descriptions for more details and see sample pictures of each item in the Image Gallery.

The History of WRESY™...

In 2011 Anthony J. Criss, the owner/operator of AJ Criss Industries (a San Diego Landscape Contracting Company with over 45 years of experience) recognized a problem within his local communities: the water from everyday landscape irrigation was running down driveways, onto streets & eventually into our sewage drains… and for Home Owners, there was no easy way to stop this unused water & hard-earned money from literally “going down the drain”.

After months of discussions with his client & friend, Cel Gaeta (an engineer with US Patent expertise), they began formulating an idea for a residential water recycling system that focused on capturing & reusing the irrigation waste water our homes produce. This exciting idea + 4 years of collaboration eventually led to the creation of the WRESY™ Water Recycling System.

WRESY™, which stands for Water Recycling System, combines a home’s pre-existing drain pipes, with easily-installed 150 gallon water drums, and WRESY’s patented system of valves and pumps into a simple and easy-to-use process to recycle and reuse irrigation run-off & rain water run-off.

The California Drought Changes Everything...

In recent years, California has experienced a water shortage, a crisis that has affected communities statewide. City and State governments have had countless debates, come up with multiple propositions, and passed several regulations in an attempt to alleviate the increasing reality of water shortages… and NOW, Facing Unprecedented drought conditions, the California State Water Board adopted water-use reduction mandates on May 5th, in order to implement Governor Jerry Brown’s April 1st 2015 executive order, for a 25% statewide reduction in urban water use.

Nearly ALL San Diego County Communities have required their residents to limit their use of outdoor water, including specific water days & times for landscapes and yards. Also, the local municipal water companies have implemented a Tiered Water System in order to measure water usage and appropriately charge home owners who choose to use more water than their neighbors… and $500 FINES for those San Diego property owners that are considered “Water Wasters”.

Now that we are into the 4th Year of the California Drought, and experts agree that there is little hope of relief in sight, we could not think of a better time to introduce the WRESY™ Water Recycling System to the World. With literally MILLIONS of Gallons of Water “running down the drain” every day in the United States... let’s work Together for a Better & Wetter Tomorrow!

Other Ways You Can Help

For more information about WRESY please visit our website at:  www.wresy.com or follow & support us on our social media profiles below:

  • Twitter - https://www.twitter.com/wresysaves
  • Facebook - https://www.facebook.com/wresywaterrecycling
  • Google+ - https://plus.google.com/101431895620212603553/p...
We are always accepting all forms of support (tools, equipment, help, suggestions, etc.). You can contact us through our website, www.wresy.com, We'd love to hear your ideas, thoughts, or advice! And if you are unable to contribute to our Indiegogo campaign, but still want to be a part of this project you can share our campaign page on your social media networks. Thank you!

story:
What's Better Than Recycling? Letting the Store Refill It! 

Like everyone else, I want to keep my home clean and I use personal care products like shampoo, and like most of us I end up having to buy those products in single-use plastic bottles. I try to recycle but China doesn't want our plastic recycling anymore. It's piling up, overflowing waste facilities, and being sent to places that aren't prepared to handle it correctly. Plastic garbage is killing sea mammals, and even ending up in our food. 

I used to wish I could take those plastic bottles back to the store and they would just wash and refill them, so the containers could be used over and over. I wanted to buy the product itself, not another bottle! And, most of all I wanted it to be as fast and convenient as buying a new one off the shelf at the grocery store. That's why we're starting Blue Dot Refillery. 

I'm so excited about this opportunity to really change the way we use plastic packaging. If we can get this first Refillery going, refine our model, and show it can be sustained, we could expand the concept to other cities and regions. This would result in keeping millions of tons of plastics out of the waste stream, and has the potential to dramatically revolutionize the way we use packaging for many products. 

This is your opportunity to be a part of a brand new retail model that could revolutionize how we think about and use plastic packaging. A business model that makes even more sense than recycling and could result in keeping millions of plastic containers out of the waste stream. 

 

The Business Plan

I worked closely with the local SBA Small Business Development Center to prepare a detailed, solid business plan using conservative estimates to minimize risk. Forecasting moderate sales, our plan showed a consistent growth in profits over three years of projections. If you would like more information about the plan, and our calculations and pro forma projections, you can email me at info@bluedotrefillery.com.

 

What We Need & What You Get

Based on our detailed business plan, we will need about $65,000 to get our first modest Refillery started. That means we need an additional $40,000. If more is donated, we'll be able to start bigger and move faster to stop the flow of plastic. If you live in the Bellingham area, you can donate and get some great perks like a starter basket of Blue Dot products in our branded containers, and refills for a year.

If you are not in our area, but you like this innovative idea and want to support our efforts, even a $5 donation will help. We'll keep you informed about our progress. If you donate $25, we'll send you a sturdy, recycled cotton grocery bag with out fabulous Blue Dot logo! Check the perks section for more. 

If we don't reach our crowdfunding goal of $40,000, it will tell us the time is not yet right for this idea and funds will be returned to the donors. 

 

What You Can Do...

Help support our efforts financially- even a small donation will bring us that much closer to showing that you CAN buy what you need without buying another plastic bottle! 

GET THE WORD OUT! Let your friends know! Tell your co-workers! All those people that you know are freaking about about plastic garbage in the oceans. All of you who hate having to dispose of another plastic bottle. Tell the world! It's time!
